<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Africa_(disambiguation)" title="Africa (disambiguation)">Africa (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

margin: 0"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Morocco.svg/23px-Flag_of_Morocco.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Morocco.svg/35px-Flag_of_Morocco.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Morocco.svg/45px-Flag_of_Morocco.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a> <i>(<a href="/wiki/Southern_Provinces" title="Southern Provinces">Southern Provinces</a>)</i></li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/23px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/35px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Flag_of_Portugal.svg/45px-Flag_of_Portugal.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> <i>(<a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeira</a>)</i></li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> <i>(<a href="/wiki/Alboran_Island" title="Alboran Island">Alboran Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ceuta" title="Ceuta">Ceuta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Melilla" title="Melilla">Melilla</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Plazas_de_soberan%C3%ADa" title="Plazas de soberanía">Plazas de soberanía</a>)</i></li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_Tanzania.svg/23px-Flag_of_Tanzania.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_Tanzania.svg/35px-Flag_of_Tanzania.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_Tanzania.svg/45px-Flag_of_Tanzania.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Tanzania" title="Tanzania">Tanzania</a> <i>(<a href="/wiki/Zanzibar" title="Zanzibar">Zanzibar</a>)</i></li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Flag_of_Yemen.svg/23px-Flag_of_Yemen.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Flag_of_Yemen.svg/35px-Flag_of_Yemen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Flag_of_Yemen.svg/45px-Flag_of_Yemen.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> <i>(<a href="/wiki/Socotra" title="Socotra">Socotra</a>)</i></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Languages</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a><br/><a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Swahili_language" title="Swahili language">Swahili</a><br/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Africa" title="Languages of Africa">1250–3000 native languages</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Time zones</th><td class="infobox-data"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC-1" title="UTC-1">UTC-1</a> to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC%2B4" title="UTC+4">UTC+4</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Largest cities</th><td class="infobox-data"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_urban_agglomerations_in_Africa" title="List of urban agglomerations in Africa">Largest urban areas</a>:<div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Lagos" title="Lagos">Lagos</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Kinshasa" title="Kinshasa">Kinshasa</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Luanda" title="Luanda">Luanda</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Khartoum" title="Khartoum">Khartoum</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Dar_es_Salaam" title="Dar es Salaam">Dar es Salaam</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Abidjan" title="Abidjan">Abidjan</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Kigali" title="Kigali">Kigali</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Nairobi" title="Nairobi">Nairobi</a></li><li style="white-space:break;"><a href="/wiki/Algiers" title="Algiers">Algiers</a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Africa</b> is the world's second-largest and second-most populous <a href="/wiki/Continent" title="Continent">continent</a>, after <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> in both cases. At about 30.3 million km<sup>2</sup> (11.7 million square miles) including adjacent islands, it covers 6% of Earth's total surface area and 20% of its land area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sayre_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sayre-7">[7]</a></sup> With 1.4 billion people<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2022_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2022-2">[2]</a></sup> as of 2021, it accounts for about <span data-sort-value="7001176207413858337♠" style="display:none"></span>18% of the world's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_population" title="Human population">human population</a>. Africa's population is the youngest amongst all the continents;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Median" title="Median">median</a> age in 2012 was 19.7, when the worldwide median age was 30.4.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> Despite a wide range of <a href="/wiki/Natural_resource" title="Natural resource">natural resources</a>, Africa is the least wealthy continent per capita and second-least wealthy by total wealth, behind <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a>. Scholars have attributed this to different factors including geography, climate, <a href="/wiki/Tribalism" title="Tribalism">tribalism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-11">[11]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Scramble_for_Africa" title="Scramble for Africa">colonialism</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neocolonialism" title="Neocolonialism">neocolonialism</a>, lack of democracy, and corruption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-11">[11]</a></sup> Despite this low concentration of wealth, recent economic expansion and the large and young population make Africa an important economic market in the broader global context.
</p><p>The continent is surrounded by the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the north, the <a href="/wiki/Isthmus_of_Suez" title="Isthmus of Suez">Isthmus of Suez</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a> to the northeast, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> to the southeast and the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> to the west. The continent includes <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">Madagascar</a> and various <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelagos</a>. It contains <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_in_Africa" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Africa">54</a> <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_recognition" title="Diplomatic recognition">fully recognised</a> <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign states</a> (<a href="/wiki/Country" title="Country">countries</a>), eight <a href="/wiki/Territory" title="Territory">territories</a> and two <i>de facto</i> independent <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">states with limited or no recognition</a>. <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a> is Africa's largest country by area, and <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> is its largest by population. African nations cooperate through the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a>, which is headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>.
</p><p>Africa straddles the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Prime_meridian" title="Prime meridian">prime meridian</a>. It is the only continent to stretch from the northern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperate" title="Temperate">temperate</a> to southern temperate zones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> The majority of the continent and its countries are in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</a>, with a substantial portion and number of countries in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>. Most of the continent lies in the tropics, except for a large part of <a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">Western Sahara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, the northern tip of <a href="/wiki/Mauritania" title="Mauritania">Mauritania</a>, the entire territories of <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ceuta" title="Ceuta">Ceuta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Melilla" title="Melilla">Melilla</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> which in turn are located above the <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Cancer" title="Tropic of Cancer">tropic of Cancer</a>, in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperate_zone" title="Temperate zone">northern temperate zone</a>. In the other extreme of the continent, southern <a href="/wiki/Namibia" title="Namibia">Namibia</a>, southern <a href="/wiki/Botswana" title="Botswana">Botswana</a>, great parts of <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>, the entire territories of <a href="/wiki/Lesotho" title="Lesotho">Lesotho</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eswatini" title="Eswatini">Eswatini</a> and the southern tips of <a href="/wiki/Mozambique" title="Mozambique">Mozambique</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">Madagascar</a> are located below the <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Capricorn" title="Tropic of Capricorn">tropic of Capricorn</a>, in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperate_zone" title="Temperate zone">southern temperate zone</a>.
</p><p>Africa is highly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biodiverse" title="Biodiverse">biodiverse</a>; it is the continent with the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Megafauna" title="Megafauna">megafauna</a> species, as it was least affected by the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary_extinction_event#The_Pleistocene_or_Ice_Age_extinction_event" title="Quaternary extinction event">extinction of the Pleistocene megafauna</a>. However, Africa also is <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Africa" title="Environmental issues in Africa">heavily affected by a wide range of environmental issues</a>, including desertification, deforestation, <a href="/wiki/Water_scarcity" title="Water scarcity">water scarcity</a>, pollution and other issues. These entrenched environmental concerns are expected to worsen as <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Africa" title="Climate change in Africa">climate change impacts Africa</a>. The UN <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmental_Panel_on_Climate_Change" title="Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change">Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change</a> has identified Africa as the continent most <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_vulnerability" title="Climate change vulnerability">vulnerable to climate change</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:10Africa_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-:10Africa-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/History_of_Africa" title="History of Africa">history of Africa</a> is long, complex, and has often been under-appreciated by the global <a href="/wiki/African_historiography" title="African historiography">historical community</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Africa, particularly <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">Eastern Africa</a>, is widely accepted as the place of origin of humans and the <a href="/wiki/Hominidae" title="Hominidae">Hominidae</a> <a href="/wiki/Clade" title="Clade">clade</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_ape" title="Great ape">great apes</a>). The earliest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hominids" title="Hominids">hominids</a> and their ancestors have been dated to around 7 million years ago, including <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sahelanthropus_tchadensis" title="Sahelanthropus tchadensis">Sahelanthropus tchadensis</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Australopithecus_africanus" title="Australopithecus africanus">Australopithecus africanus</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Australopithecus_afarensis" title="Australopithecus afarensis">A. afarensis</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_habilis" title="Homo habilis">H. habilis</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_ergaster" title="Homo ergaster">H. ergaster</a></i>— the earliest <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i> (modern human) remains, found in <a href="/wiki/Omo_remains" title="Omo remains">Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florisbad_Skull" title="Florisbad Skull">South Africa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jebel_Irhoud" title="Jebel Irhoud">Morocco</a>, date to circa 233,000, 259,000, and 300,000 years ago respectively, and <i>Homo sapiens</i> is believed to have originated in Africa around 350,000–260,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Africa is also considered by anthropologists to be the most genetically diverse continent as a result of being the longest inhabited.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Early human civilizations, such as <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carthage" title="Carthage">Carthage</a> emerged in <a href="/wiki/History_of_North_Africa" title="History of North Africa">North Africa</a>. Following a subsequent <a href="/wiki/List_of_kingdoms_in_pre-colonial_Africa" title="List of kingdoms in pre-colonial Africa">long and complex history of civilizations</a>, migration and trade, Africa hosts a large diversity of <a href="/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_of_Africa" title="List of ethnic groups of Africa">ethnicities</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Africa" title="Culture of Africa">cultures</a> and <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Africa" title="Languages of Africa">languages</a>. The last 400 years have witnessed an increasing European influence on the continent. Starting in the 16th century, this was driven by trade, including the <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Africa" title="Slavery in Africa">Trans-Atlantic slave trade</a>, which created large <a href="/wiki/African_diaspora" title="African diaspora">African diaspora</a> populations in the Americas. From the <a href="/wiki/New_Imperialism" title="New Imperialism">late 19th century</a> to  the early 20th century, European nations <a href="/wiki/Scramble_for_Africa" title="Scramble for Africa">colonized almost all of Africa</a>, with the exception of <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a>, though Ethiopia would later be <a href="/wiki/Second_Italo-Ethiopian_War" title="Second Italo-Ethiopian War">invaded</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_Ethiopia" title="Italian Ethiopia">occupied</a> by <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italy</a> from 1936 to 1941.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Most present states in Africa emerged from a process of <a href="/wiki/Decolonisation_of_Africa" title="Decolonisation of Africa">decolonisation</a> following <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-37"><a href="#Sources"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">Sources</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-38"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-39"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AS17-148-22733_(21516723298).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4275" data-file-width="4275" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/AS17-148-22733_%2821516723298%29.jpg/220px-AS17-148-22733_%2821516723298%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/AS17-148-22733_%2821516723298%29.jpg/330px-AS17-148-22733_%2821516723298%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/AS17-148-22733_%2821516723298%29.jpg/440px-AS17-148-22733_%2821516723298%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AS17-148-22733_(21516723298).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The totality of Africa seen by the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_17" title="Apollo 17">Apollo 17</a> crew</div></div></div>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Afri" title="Afri">Afri</a></i> was a <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> name used to refer to the inhabitants of then-known northern Africa to the west of the <a href="/wiki/Nile" title="Nile">Nile</a> river, and in its widest sense referred to all lands south of the Mediterranean (<a href="/wiki/Ancient_Libya" title="Ancient Libya">Ancient Libya</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> This name seems to have originally referred to a <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Libya" title="Ancient Libya">native Libyan</a> tribe, an ancestor of modern <a href="/wiki/Berbers" title="Berbers">Berbers</a>; see <a href="/wiki/Terence#Biography" title="Terence">Terence</a> for discussion. The name had usually been connected with the <a href="/wiki/Phoenician_language" title="Phoenician language">Phoenician</a> word <i><span title="Phoenician-language text"><i lang="phn">ʿafar</i></span></i> meaning "dust",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> but a 1981 hypothesis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> has asserted that it stems from the <a href="/wiki/Berber_languages" title="Berber languages">Berber</a> word <i>ifri</i> (plural <i>ifran</i>) meaning "cave", in reference to cave dwellers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Michell_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-Michell-37">[37]</a></sup> The same word<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Michell_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-Michell-37">[37]</a></sup> may be found in the name of the <a href="/wiki/Banu_Ifran" title="Banu Ifran">Banu Ifran</a> from <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tripolitania" title="Tripolitania">Tripolitania</a>, a Berber tribe originally from <a href="/wiki/Yafran" title="Yafran">Yafran</a> (also known as <i>Ifrane</i>) in northwestern Libya,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> as well as the city of <a href="/wiki/Ifrane" title="Ifrane">Ifrane</a> in Morocco.
</p><p>Under <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a> rule, <a href="/wiki/Carthage" title="Carthage">Carthage</a> became the capital of the province it then named <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Africa_Proconsularis" title="Africa Proconsularis">Africa Proconsularis</a></i>, following its defeat of the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Carthage" title="Ancient Carthage">Carthaginians</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Third_Punic_War" title="Third Punic War">Third Punic War</a> in 146 BC, which also included the coastal part of modern <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> The Latin suffix <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ica#Latin" title="wikt:-ica">-ica</a></i> can sometimes be used to denote a land (e.g., in <i><a href="/wiki/Gallia_Celtica" title="Gallia Celtica">Celtica</a></i> from <i><a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celtae</a></i>, as used by <a href="/wiki/Julius_Caesar" title="Julius Caesar">Julius Caesar</a>). The later Muslim region of <a href="/wiki/Ifriqiya" title="Ifriqiya">Ifriqiya</a>, following its conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine (Eastern Roman)</a> Empire's <i><a href="/wiki/Exarchate_of_Africa" title="Exarchate of Africa">Exarchatus Africae</a></i>, also preserved a form of the name.
</p><p>According to the Romans, Africa lies to the west of Egypt, while "Asia" was used to refer to <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> and lands to the east. A definite line was drawn between the two continents by the geographer <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a> (85–165 AD), indicating <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prime_Meridian" title="Prime Meridian">Prime Meridian</a> and making the isthmus of Suez and the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a> the boundary between Asia and Africa. As Europeans came to understand the real extent of the continent, the idea of "Africa" expanded with their knowledge.
</p><p>Other etymological hypotheses have been postulated for the ancient name "Africa":
</p>
<ul><li>The 1st-century Jewish historian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flavius_Josephus" title="Flavius Josephus">Flavius Josephus</a> (<i>Ant. 1.15</i>) asserted that it was named for <a href="/wiki/Epher" title="Epher">Epher</a>, grandson of <a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a> according to Gen. 25:4, whose descendants, he claimed, had invaded Libya.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Isidore_of_Seville" title="Isidore of Seville">Isidore of Seville</a> in his 7th-century <i><a href="/wiki/Etymologiae" title="Etymologiae">Etymologiae</a></i> XIV.5.2. suggests "Africa comes from the <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> <i>aprica</i>, meaning "sunny".</li>
<li>Massey, in 1881, stated that Africa is derived from the Egyptian <i>af-rui-ka</i>, meaning "to turn toward the opening of the Ka." The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Egyptian_soul#Ka" title="Egyptian soul">Ka</a> is the energetic double of every person and the "opening of the Ka" refers to a womb or birthplace. Africa would be, for the Egyptians, "the birthplace."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup></li>
<li>Michèle Fruyt in 1976 proposed<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> linking the Latin word with <i>africus</i> "south wind", which would be of Umbrian origin and mean originally "rainy wind".</li>
<li>Robert R. Stieglitz of <a href="/wiki/Rutgers_University" title="Rutgers University">Rutgers University</a> in 1984 proposed: "The name Africa, derived from the Latin *Aphir-ic-a, is cognate to Hebrew <a href="/wiki/Ophir" title="Ophir">Ophir</a> ['rich']."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ibn_Khallikan" title="Ibn Khallikan">Ibn Khallikan</a> and some other historians claim that the name of Africa came from a <a href="/wiki/Himyarite_Kingdom" title="Himyarite Kingdom">Himyarite</a> king called Afrikin ibn Kais ibn Saifi also called "Afrikus son of Abraham" who subdued Ifriqiya.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup></li>
<li>Arabic <i>afrīqā</i> (feminine noun) and <i>ifrīqiyā</i>, now usually pronounced <i>afrīqiyā</i> (feminine) 'Africa', from <i>‘afara</i> [‘ = <i>‘ain</i>, not <i>’alif</i>] 'to be dusty' from <i>‘afar</i> 'dust, powder' and <i>‘afir</i> 'dried, dried up by the sun, withered' and <i>‘affara</i> 'to dry in the sun on hot sand' or 'to sprinkle with dust'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup></li>
<li>Possibly Phoenician <i>faraqa</i> in the sense of 'colony, separation'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Africa" title="History of Africa">History of Africa</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_North_Africa" title="History of North Africa">History of North Africa</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_West_Africa" title="History of West Africa">History of West Africa</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Central_Africa" title="History of Central Africa">History of Central Africa</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_East_Africa" title="History of East Africa">History of East Africa</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Southern_Africa" title="History of Southern Africa">History of Southern Africa</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Recent_African_origin_of_modern_humans" title="Recent African origin of modern humans">Recent African origin of modern humans</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lucy_blackbg.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2413" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="362" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Lucy_blackbg.jpg/150px-Lucy_blackbg.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Lucy_blackbg.jpg/225px-Lucy_blackbg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Lucy_blackbg.jpg/300px-Lucy_blackbg.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lucy_blackbg.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lucy_(Australopithecus)" title="Lucy (Australopithecus)">Lucy</a>, an <i><a href="/wiki/Australopithecus_afarensis" title="Australopithecus afarensis">Australopithecus afarensis</a></i> skeleton discovered 24 November 1974 in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Awash_Valley" title="Awash Valley">Awash Valley</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afar_Depression" title="Afar Depression">Afar Depression</a></div></div></div>
<p>Africa is considered by most <a href="/wiki/Paleoanthropology" title="Paleoanthropology">paleoanthropologists</a> to be the <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_Humankind" title="Cradle of Humankind">oldest inhabited territory</a> on Earth, with the Human species originating from the continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HerreraGarcia-Bertrand2018_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-HerreraGarcia-Bertrand2018-48">[48]</a></sup> During the mid-20th century, <a href="/wiki/Anthropology" title="Anthropology">anthropologists</a> discovered many <a href="/wiki/Fossil" title="Fossil">fossils</a> and evidence of human occupation perhaps as early as 7 million years ago (BP=before present). Fossil remains of several species of early apelike humans thought to have <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">evolved</a> into modern man, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Australopithecus_afarensis" title="Australopithecus afarensis">Australopithecus afarensis</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Radiometric_dating" title="Radiometric dating">radiometrically dated</a> to approximately 3.9–3.0 million years BP,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Paranthropus_boisei" title="Paranthropus boisei">Paranthropus boisei</a></i> (c. 2.3–1.4 million years BP)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_ergaster" title="Homo ergaster">Homo ergaster</a></i> (c. 1.9 million–600,000 years BP) have been discovered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sayre_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sayre-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the evolution of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i> approximately 350,000 to 260,000 years BP in Africa,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schlebusch2017_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-Schlebusch2017-23">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20190910_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20190910-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NAT-20190910_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-NAT-20190910-26">[26]</a></sup> the continent was mainly populated by groups of <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> These first modern humans left Africa and populated the rest of the globe during the <a href="/wiki/Recent_African_origin_of_modern_humans" title="Recent African origin of modern humans">Out of Africa II</a> migration dated to approximately 50,000 years BP, exiting the continent either across <a href="/wiki/Bab-el-Mandeb" title="Bab-el-Mandeb">Bab-el-Mandeb</a> over the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar" title="Strait of Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a> in Morocco,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> or the <a href="/wiki/Isthmus_of_Suez" title="Isthmus of Suez">Isthmus of Suez</a> in Egypt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other migrations of modern humans within the African continent have been dated to that time, with evidence of early human settlement found in Southern Africa, Southeast Africa, North Africa, and the <a href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Emergence_of_civilization">Emergence of civilization</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization#Ancient_Egypt" title="Cradle of civilization">Cradle of civilization § Ancient Egypt</a></div>
<p>The size of the Sahara has historically been extremely variable, with its area rapidly fluctuating and at times disappearing depending on global climatic conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> At the end of the <a href="/wiki/Ice_age" title="Ice age">Ice ages</a>, estimated to have been around 10,500 BC, the Sahara had again become a green fertile valley, and its African populations returned from the interior and coastal highlands in <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Saharan_rock_art" title="Saharan rock art">rock art paintings</a> depicting a fertile Sahara and large populations discovered in <a href="/wiki/Tassili_n%27Ajjer" title="Tassili n'Ajjer">Tassili n'Ajjer</a> dating back perhaps 10 millennia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> However, the warming and drying climate meant that by 5000 BC, the Sahara region was becoming increasingly dry and hostile. Around 3500 BC, due to a tilt in the earth's orbit, the Sahara experienced a period of rapid desertification.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> The population trekked out of the Sahara region towards the Nile Valley below the <a href="/wiki/Cataracts_of_the_Nile" title="Cataracts of the Nile">Second Cataract</a> where they made permanent or semi-permanent settlements. A major climatic recession occurred, lessening the heavy and persistent rains in Central and <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">Eastern Africa</a>. Since this time, dry conditions have prevailed in Eastern Africa and, increasingly during the last 200 years, in <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a>.
</p><p>The domestication of cattle in Africa preceded agriculture and seems to have existed alongside hunter-gatherer cultures. It is speculated that by 6000 BC, cattle were domesticated in North Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> In the Sahara-Nile complex, people domesticated many animals, including the donkey and a small screw-horned goat which was common from <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a> to <a href="/wiki/Nubia" title="Nubia">Nubia</a>.
</p><p>Between 10,000 and 9,000 BC, pottery was independently invented in the region of Mali in the savannah of West Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pottery_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pottery-63">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-swissinfo_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-swissinfo-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mathendous_giraffes.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Mathendous_giraffes.jpg/220px-Mathendous_giraffes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Mathendous_giraffes.jpg/330px-Mathendous_giraffes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Mathendous_giraffes.jpg/440px-Mathendous_giraffes.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mathendous_giraffes.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Saharan_rock_art" title="Saharan rock art">Saharan rock art</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Fezzan" title="Fezzan">Fezzan</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Savanna" title="Savanna">savannahs</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sahel" title="Sahel">Sahel</a> in Northern West Africa, people possibly ancestral to modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nilo-Saharan" title="Nilo-Saharan">Nilo-Saharan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mand%C3%A9" title="Mandé">Mandé</a> cultures started to collect wild <a href="/wiki/Millet" title="Millet">millet</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> around 8000 to 6000 BC. Later, <a href="/wiki/Gourd" title="Gourd">gourds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Watermelon" title="Watermelon">watermelons</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Castor_bean" title="Castor bean">castor beans</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a> were also collected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Sorghum was first domesticated in Eastern Sudan around 4000 BC, in one of the earliest instances of agriculture in human history. Its cultivation would gradually spread across Africa, before spreading to India around 2000 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sorghum" title="Sorghum">Sorghum</a> was first domesticated in the<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (June 2022)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. They also started making <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">pottery</a> and built stone settlements (e.g., <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tichitt" title="Tichitt">Tichitt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oualata" title="Oualata">Oualata</a>). Fishing, using bone-tipped <a href="/wiki/Harpoon" title="Harpoon">harpoons</a>, became a major activity in the numerous streams and lakes formed from the increased rains.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> In West Africa, the wet phase ushered in an expanding <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforest</a> and wooded savanna from <a href="/wiki/Senegal" title="Senegal">Senegal</a> to <a href="/wiki/Cameroon" title="Cameroon">Cameroon</a>. Between 9,000 and 5,000 BC, <a href="/wiki/Niger%E2%80%93Congo_languages" title="Niger–Congo languages">Niger–Congo speakers</a> domesticated the <a href="/wiki/Elaeis_guineensis" title="Elaeis guineensis">oil palm</a> and <a href="/wiki/Raffia_palm" title="Raffia palm">raffia palm</a>. <a href="/wiki/Black-eyed_pea" title="Black-eyed pea">Black-eyed peas</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Voandzeia" title="Voandzeia">voandzeia</a> (African groundnuts), were domesticated, followed by <a href="/wiki/Okra" title="Okra">okra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kola_nut" title="Kola nut">kola nuts</a>. Since most of the plants grew in the forest, the Niger–Congo speakers invented polished stone axes for clearing forest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around 4000 BC, the Saharan climate started to become drier at an exceedingly fast pace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O'Brien_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-O'Brien-71">[71]</a></sup> This climate change caused lakes and rivers to shrink significantly and caused increasing <a href="/wiki/Desertification" title="Desertification">desertification</a>. This, in turn, decreased the amount of land conducive to settlements and encouraged migrations of farming communities to the more tropical climate of West Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O'Brien_71-1"><a href="#cite_note-O'Brien-71">[71]</a></sup> During the first millennium BC, a reduction in wild grain populations related to changing climate conditions facilitated the expansion of farming communities and the rapid adoption of rice cultivation around the Niger River.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the first millennium BC, <a href="/wiki/Ferrous_metallurgy" title="Ferrous metallurgy">ironworking</a> had been introduced in Northern Africa. Around that time it also became established in parts of sub-Saharan Africa, either through independent invention there or diffusion from the north<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PB_2014_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-PB_2014-75">[75]</a></sup> and vanished under unknown circumstances around 500 AD, having lasted approximately 2,000 years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FB_1969_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FB_1969-76">[76]</a></sup> and by 500 BC, metalworking began to become commonplace in West Africa. Ironworking was fully established by roughly 500 BC in many areas of East and West Africa, although other regions didn't begin ironworking until the early centuries AD. Copper objects from <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, North Africa, Nubia, and Ethiopia dating from around 500 BC have been excavated in West Africa, suggesting that <a href="/wiki/Trans-Saharan_trade" title="Trans-Saharan trade">Trans-Saharan trade</a> networks had been established by this date.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O'Brien_71-2"><a href="#cite_note-O'Brien-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_civilizations">Early civilizations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_African_history" title="Ancient African history">Ancient African history</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:African-civilizations-map-pre-colonial.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1295" data-file-width="1390" decoding="async" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/African-civilizations-map-pre-colonial.svg/260px-African-civilizations-map-pre-colonial.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/African-civilizations-map-pre-colonial.svg/390px-African-civilizations-map-pre-colonial.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/African-civilizations-map-pre-colonial.svg/520px-African-civilizations-map-pre-colonial.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:African-civilizations-map-pre-colonial.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Diachronic map showing <a href="/wiki/African_empires" title="African empires">African empires</a> spanning roughly 500 BCE to 1500 CE</div></div></div>
<p>At about 3300 BC, the historical record opens in Northern Africa with the rise of literacy in the <a href="/wiki/Pharaoh" title="Pharaoh">Pharaonic</a> civilization of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> One of the world's earliest and longest-lasting civilizations, the Egyptian state continued, with varying levels of influence over other areas, until 343 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Egyptian influence reached deep into modern-day <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Libya" title="Ancient Libya">Libya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nubia" title="Nubia">Nubia</a>, and, according to Martin Bernal, as far north as Crete.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>An independent centre of <a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">civilization</a> with trading links to <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicia</a> was established by <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicians</a> from <a href="/wiki/Tyre,_Lebanon" title="Tyre, Lebanon">Tyre</a> on the north-west African coast at <a href="/wiki/Carthage" title="Carthage">Carthage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/European_exploration_of_Africa" title="European exploration of Africa">European exploration of Africa</a> began with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Greeks" title="Ancient Greeks">Ancient Greeks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Romans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> In 332 BC, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> was welcomed as a liberator in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Ptolemaic_Egypt" title="History of Ptolemaic Egypt">Persian-occupied Egypt</a>. He founded <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> in Egypt, which would become the prosperous capital of the <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_dynasty" title="Ptolemaic dynasty">Ptolemaic dynasty</a> after his death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the conquest of North Africa's Mediterranean coastline by the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, the area was integrated economically and culturally into the Roman system. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Africa_Province" title="Africa Province">Roman settlement</a> occurred in modern Tunisia and elsewhere along the coast. The first <a href="/wiki/Roman_emperor" title="Roman emperor">Roman emperor</a> native to North Africa was <a href="/wiki/Septimius_Severus" title="Septimius Severus">Septimius Severus</a>, born in <a href="/wiki/Leptis_Magna" title="Leptis Magna">Leptis Magna</a> in present-day Libya—his mother was Italian Roman and his father was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punics" title="Punics">Punic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aksum,_iscrizione_di_re_ezana,_in_greco,_sabeo_e_ge%27ez,_330-350_dc_ca._10.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5022" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="320" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Aksum%2C_iscrizione_di_re_ezana%2C_in_greco%2C_sabeo_e_ge%27ez%2C_330-350_dc_ca._10.jpg/220px-Aksum%2C_iscrizione_di_re_ezana%2C_in_greco%2C_sabeo_e_ge%27ez%2C_330-350_dc_ca._10.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Aksum%2C_iscrizione_di_re_ezana%2C_in_greco%2C_sabeo_e_ge%27ez%2C_330-350_dc_ca._10.jpg/330px-Aksum%2C_iscrizione_di_re_ezana%2C_in_greco%2C_sabeo_e_ge%27ez%2C_330-350_dc_ca._10.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Aksum%2C_iscrizione_di_re_ezana%2C_in_greco%2C_sabeo_e_ge%27ez%2C_330-350_dc_ca._10.jpg/440px-Aksum%2C_iscrizione_di_re_ezana%2C_in_greco%2C_sabeo_e_ge%27ez%2C_330-350_dc_ca._10.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aksum,_iscrizione_di_re_ezana,_in_greco,_sabeo_e_ge%27ez,_330-350_dc_ca._10.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Ezana_Stone" title="Ezana Stone">Ezana Stone</a> records King Ezana's conversion to Christianity and his subjugation of various neighboring peoples, including <a href="/wiki/Mero%C3%AB" title="Meroë">Meroë</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Christianity spread across these areas at an early date, from Judaea via Egypt and beyond the borders of the Roman world into Nubia;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> by AD 340 at the latest, it had become the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aksumite_Empire" title="Aksumite Empire">Aksumite Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Frumentius" title="Frumentius">Syro-Greek missionaries</a>, who arrived by way of the Red Sea, were responsible for this theological development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 7th century, the newly formed Arabian Islamic <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">Caliphate</a> expanded into Egypt, and then into North Africa. In a short while, the local Berber elite had been integrated into Muslim Arab tribes. When the Umayyad capital Damascus fell in the 8th century, the Islamic centre of the Mediterranean shifted from Syria to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qayrawan" title="Qayrawan">Qayrawan</a> in North Africa. Islamic North Africa had become diverse, and a hub for mystics, scholars, jurists, and philosophers. During the above-mentioned period, Islam spread to sub-Saharan Africa, mainly through trade routes and migration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ayoub_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ayoub-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>In West Africa, <a href="/wiki/Dhar_Tichitt" title="Dhar Tichitt">Dhar Tichitt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oualata" title="Oualata">Oualata</a> in present-day <a href="/wiki/Mauritania" title="Mauritania">Mauritania</a> figure prominently among the early urban centers, dated to 2,000 BC. About 500 stone settlements litter the region in the former savannah of the Sahara. Its inhabitants fished and grew millet. It has been found by Augustin Holl that the <a href="/wiki/Soninke_people" title="Soninke people">Soninke</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Mand%C3%A9_peoples" title="Mandé peoples">Mandé peoples</a> were likely responsible for constructing such settlements. Around 300 BC the region became more desiccated and the settlements began to decline, most likely relocating to <a href="/wiki/Koumbi_Saleh" title="Koumbi Saleh">Koumbi Saleh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HollA1985_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-HollA1985-91">[91]</a></sup> Architectural evidence and the comparison of pottery styles suggest that Dhar Tichitt was related to the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Empire" title="Ghana Empire">Ghana Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Djenn%C3%A9-Djenno" title="Djenné-Djenno">Djenné-Djenno</a> (in present-day <a href="/wiki/Mali" title="Mali">Mali</a>) was settled around 300 BC, and the town grew to house a sizable <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> population, as evidenced by crowded cemeteries. Living structures were made of sun-dried mud. By 250 BC <a href="/wiki/Djenn%C3%A9-Djenno" title="Djenné-Djenno">Djenné-Djenno</a> had become a large, thriving market town.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Farther south, in central <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>, around 1,500 BC, the <a href="/wiki/Nok_culture" title="Nok culture">Nok culture</a> developed on the <a href="/wiki/Jos_Plateau" title="Jos Plateau">Jos Plateau</a>. It was a highly centralized community. The Nok people produced lifelike representations in <a href="/wiki/Terracotta" title="Terracotta">terracotta</a>, including human heads and human figures, elephants, and other animals. By 500 BC, and possibly earlier, they were smelting iron. By 200 AD the Nok culture had vanished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PB_2014_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-PB_2014-75">[75]</a></sup> and vanished under unknown circumstances around 500 AD, having lasted approximately 2,000 years. Based on stylistic similarities with the Nok terracottas, the bronze figurines of the <a href="/wiki/Yoruba_people" title="Yoruba people">Yoruba</a> kingdom of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ife" title="Ife">Ife</a> and those of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bini_people" title="Bini people">Bini</a> kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Benin" title="Benin">Benin</a> are suggested to be continuations of the traditions of the earlier Nok culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShillington200539_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShillington200539-94">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FB_1969_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-FB_1969-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ninth_to_eighteenth_centuries">Ninth to eighteenth centuries</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bronze_ornamental_staff_head,_9th_century,_Igbo-Ukwu.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Bronze_ornamental_staff_head%2C_9th_century%2C_Igbo-Ukwu.JPG/170px-Bronze_ornamental_staff_head%2C_9th_century%2C_Igbo-Ukwu.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Bronze_ornamental_staff_head%2C_9th_century%2C_Igbo-Ukwu.JPG/255px-Bronze_ornamental_staff_head%2C_9th_century%2C_Igbo-Ukwu.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Bronze_ornamental_staff_head%2C_9th_century%2C_Igbo-Ukwu.JPG/340px-Bronze_ornamental_staff_head%2C_9th_century%2C_Igbo-Ukwu.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bronze_ornamental_staff_head,_9th_century,_Igbo-Ukwu.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The intricate 9th-century bronzes from <a href="/wiki/Archaeology_of_Igbo-Ukwu" title="Archaeology of Igbo-Ukwu">Igbo-Ukwu</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> displayed a level of technical accomplishment that was notably more advanced than European bronze casting of the same period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Honour-2005_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-Honour-2005-95">[95]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Pre-colonial Africa possessed perhaps as many as 10,000 different states and polities<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> characterized by many different sorts of political organization and rule. These included small family groups of hunter-gatherers such as the <a href="/wiki/San_people" title="San people">San people</a> of southern Africa; larger, more structured groups such as the family clan groupings of the <a href="/wiki/Bantu_languages" title="Bantu languages">Bantu-speaking</a> <a href="/wiki/Bantu_peoples" title="Bantu peoples">peoples</a> of central, southern, and eastern Africa; heavily structured clan groups in the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a>; the large <a href="/wiki/Sahelian_kingdoms" title="Sahelian kingdoms">Sahelian kingdoms</a>; and autonomous city-states and kingdoms such as those of the <a href="/wiki/Akan_people" title="Akan people">Akan</a>; <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Benin" title="Kingdom of Benin">Edo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yoruba_people" title="Yoruba people">Yoruba</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Igbo_people" title="Igbo people">Igbo people</a> in West Africa; and the <a href="/wiki/Swahili_people" title="Swahili people">Swahili</a> coastal trading towns of Southeast Africa.
</p><p>By the ninth century AD, a string of dynastic states, including the earliest <a href="/wiki/Hausa_Kingdoms" title="Hausa Kingdoms">Hausa</a> states, stretched across the sub-Saharan savannah from the western regions to central Sudan. The most powerful of these states were <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Empire" title="Ghana Empire">Ghana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gao_Region" title="Gao Region">Gao</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kanem_Empire" title="Kanem Empire">Kanem-Bornu Empire</a>. Ghana declined in the eleventh century, but was succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Mali_Empire" title="Mali Empire">Mali Empire</a> which consolidated much of western Sudan in the thirteenth century. Kanem accepted Islam in the eleventh century.
</p><p>In the forested regions of the West African coast, independent kingdoms grew with little influence from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> north. The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Nri" title="Kingdom of Nri">Kingdom of Nri</a> was established around the ninth century and was one of the first. It is also one of the oldest kingdoms in present-day <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> and was ruled by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eze_Nri" title="Eze Nri">Eze Nri</a>. The Nri kingdom is famous for its elaborate <a href="/wiki/Igbo-Ukwu#Bronzes" title="Igbo-Ukwu">bronzes</a>, found at the town of <a href="/wiki/Igbo-Ukwu" title="Igbo-Ukwu">Igbo-Ukwu</a>. The bronzes have been dated from as far back as the ninth century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/If%E1%BA%B9" title="Ifẹ">Kingdom of Ife</a>, historically the first of these Yoruba city-states or kingdoms, established government under a priestly <a href="/wiki/Oba_(ruler)" title="Oba (ruler)">oba</a> ('king' or 'ruler' in the <a href="/wiki/Yoruba_language" title="Yoruba language">Yoruba language</a>), called the <i>Ooni of Ife</i>. Ife was noted as a major religious and cultural centre in West Africa, and for its unique naturalistic tradition of bronze sculpture. The Ife model of government was adapted at the <a href="/wiki/Oyo_Empire" title="Oyo Empire">Oyo Empire</a>, where its obas or kings, called the <i>Alaafins of Oyo</i>, once controlled a large number of other Yoruba and non-Yoruba city-states and kingdoms; the <a href="/wiki/Fon_people" title="Fon people">Fon</a> <i>Kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Dahomey" title="Dahomey">Dahomey</a></i> was one of the non-Yoruba domains under Oyo control.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Great_Zimbabwe_Closeup.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="270" data-file-width="450" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Great_Zimbabwe_Closeup.jpg/220px-Great_Zimbabwe_Closeup.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Great_Zimbabwe_Closeup.jpg/330px-Great_Zimbabwe_Closeup.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Great_Zimbabwe_Closeup.jpg/440px-Great_Zimbabwe_Closeup.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Great_Zimbabwe_Closeup.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ruins of <a href="/wiki/Great_Zimbabwe" title="Great Zimbabwe">Great Zimbabwe</a> (flourished eleventh to fifteenth centuries)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Almoravid_dynasty" title="Almoravid dynasty">Almoravids</a> were a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Berber_people" title="Berber people">Berber</a> dynasty from the <a href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara</a> that spread over a wide area of northwestern Africa and the Iberian peninsula during the eleventh century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Banu_Hilal" title="Banu Hilal">Banu Hilal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maqil" title="Maqil">Banu Ma'qil</a> were a collection of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab" title="Arab">Arab</a> <a href="/wiki/Bedouin" title="Bedouin">Bedouin</a> tribes from the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> who migrated westwards via Egypt between the eleventh and thirteenth centuries. Their <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">migration</a> resulted in the fusion of the Arabs and Berbers, where the locals were <a href="/wiki/Arabization" title="Arabization">Arabized</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> and Arab culture absorbed elements of the local culture, under the unifying framework of Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the breakup of Mali, a local leader named <a href="/wiki/Sonni_Ali" title="Sonni Ali">Sonni Ali</a> (1464–1492) founded the <a href="/wiki/Songhai_Empire" title="Songhai Empire">Songhai Empire</a> in the region of middle <a href="/wiki/Niger" title="Niger">Niger</a> and the western <a href="/wiki/Sudan_(region)" title="Sudan (region)">Sudan</a> and took control of the trans-Saharan trade. Sonni Ali seized <a href="/wiki/Timbuktu" title="Timbuktu">Timbuktu</a> in 1468 and <a href="/wiki/Djenn%C3%A9" title="Djenné">Jenne</a> in 1473, building his regime on trade revenues and the cooperation of Muslim merchants. His successor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Askia_Mohammad_I" title="Askia Mohammad I">Askia Mohammad I</a> (1493–1528) made Islam the official religion, built mosques, and brought to Gao Muslim scholars, including al-Maghili (d.1504), the founder of an important tradition of Sudanic African Muslim scholarship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-multiple_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-multiple-101">[101]</a></sup> By the eleventh century, some <a href="/wiki/Hausa_Kingdoms" title="Hausa Kingdoms">Hausa</a> states – such as <a href="/wiki/Kano_(city)" title="Kano (city)">Kano</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jigawa" title="Jigawa">jigawa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Katsina" title="Katsina">Katsina</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gobir" title="Gobir">Gobir</a> – had developed into walled towns engaging in trade, servicing <a href="/wiki/Camel_train" title="Camel train">caravans</a>, and the manufacture of goods. Until the fifteenth century, these small states were on the periphery of the major Sudanic empires of the era, paying tribute to Songhai to the west and Kanem-Borno to the east.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Height_of_the_slave_trade">Height of the slave trade</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Trans-Saharan_slave_trade" title="Trans-Saharan slave trade">Trans-Saharan slave trade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">Atlantic slave trade</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean_slave_trade" title="Indian Ocean slave trade">Indian Ocean slave trade</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Africa_slave_Regions.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1440" data-file-width="1525" decoding="async" height="246" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Africa_slave_Regions.svg/260px-Africa_slave_Regions.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Africa_slave_Regions.svg/390px-Africa_slave_Regions.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Africa_slave_Regions.svg/520px-Africa_slave_Regions.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Africa_slave_Regions.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Major slave trading regions of Africa, 15th–19th centuries.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">Slavery</a> had long been practiced in Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Between the 15th and the 19th centuries, the Atlantic slave trade took an estimated 7–12 million slaves to the New World.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> In addition, more than 1 million Europeans were captured by <a href="/wiki/Barbary_pirates" title="Barbary pirates">Barbary pirates</a> and sold as slaves in North Africa between the 16th and 19th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>In West Africa, the decline of the Atlantic slave trade in the 1820s caused dramatic economic shifts in local polities. The gradual decline of slave-trading, prompted by a lack of demand for slaves in the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>, increasing <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism" title="Abolitionism">anti-slavery</a> legislation in Europe and America, and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">British Royal Navy's</a> increasing presence off the West African coast, obliged African states to adopt new economies. Between 1808 and 1860, the British <a href="/wiki/West_Africa_Squadron" title="West Africa Squadron">West Africa Squadron</a> seized approximately 1,600 slave ships and freed 150,000 Africans who were aboard.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>Action was also taken against African leaders who refused to agree to British treaties to outlaw the trade, for example against "the usurping King of <a href="/wiki/Lagos" title="Lagos">Lagos</a>", deposed in 1851. Anti-slavery treaties were signed with over 50 African rulers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> The largest powers of West Africa (the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asante_Confederacy" title="Asante Confederacy">Asante Confederacy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Dahomey" title="Dahomey">Kingdom of Dahomey</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Oyo_Empire" title="Oyo Empire">Oyo Empire</a>) adopted different ways of adapting to the shift. Asante and Dahomey concentrated on the development of "legitimate commerce" in the form of <a href="/wiki/Palm_oil" title="Palm oil">palm oil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a>, timber and gold, forming the bedrock of West Africa's modern export trade. The Oyo Empire, unable to adapt, collapsed into civil wars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonialism">Colonialism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Colonisation_of_Africa" title="Colonisation of Africa">Colonisation of Africa</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scramble-for-Africa-1880-1913-v2.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1130" data-file-width="2280" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Scramble-for-Africa-1880-1913-v2.png/350px-Scramble-for-Africa-1880-1913-v2.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Scramble-for-Africa-1880-1913-v2.png/525px-Scramble-for-Africa-1880-1913-v2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Scramble-for-Africa-1880-1913-v2.png/700px-Scramble-for-Africa-1880-1913-v2.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Scramble-for-Africa-1880-1913-v2.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Comparison of Africa in the years 1880 and 1913</div></div></div><div class="excerpt-block"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1066933788">.mw-parser-output .excerpt-hat .mw-editsection-like{font-style:normal}</style><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">These paragraphs are an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Scramble_for_Africa" title="Scramble for Africa">Scramble for Africa</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Scramble_for_Africa&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Scramble_for_Africa" title="Scramble for Africa">Scramble for Africa</a>, also called the Partition of Africa, or Conquest of Africa,  was the invasion, annexation, division, and <a href="/wiki/Colonisation_of_Africa" title="Colonisation of Africa">colonization of most of Africa</a> by seven <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western European</a> powers during a short period known as <a href="/wiki/New_Imperialism" title="New Imperialism">New Imperialism</a> (between 1881 and 1914). The 10 percent of Africa that was under formal European control in 1870 increased to almost 90 percent by 1914, with only <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Empire" title="Ethiopian Empire">Ethiopia</a> (Abyssinia) and <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a> remaining independent, although Ethiopia would later be <a href="/wiki/Second_Italo-Ethiopian_War" title="Second Italo-Ethiopian War">invaded</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_Ethiopia" title="Italian Ethiopia">occupied</a> by <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italy</a> for five years, from 1936 to 1941.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p>
The <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Conference" title="Berlin Conference">Berlin Conference</a> of 1884, which regulated European colonization and trade in Africa, is usually accepted as the beginning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> In the last quarter of the 19th century, there were considerable political rivalries within the empires of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_continent" title="European continent">European continent</a>, leading to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_continent" title="African continent">African continent</a> being partitioned without wars between European nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> The later years of the 19th century saw a transition from "<a href="/wiki/Informal_empire" title="Informal empire">informal imperialism</a>" – military influence and economic dominance – to direct rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShillington2005301_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShillington2005301-114">[114]</a></sup></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_struggles">Independence struggles</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Africa_in_1939.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="360" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Map_of_Africa_in_1939.png/220px-Map_of_Africa_in_1939.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Map_of_Africa_in_1939.png/330px-Map_of_Africa_in_1939.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fd/Map_of_Africa_in_1939.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Africa_in_1939.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>European control in 1939 <table style="width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0px 0px;border:none"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td> <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:orange; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Belgian_colonial_empire" title="Belgian colonial empire">Belgian</a></div></td><td> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#77DD77; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Italian_Empire" title="Italian Empire">Italian</a></div></td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#DC143C; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British</a></div></td><td> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#964B00; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a></div></td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#2A52BE; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">French</a></div></td><td> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#7FFFD4; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</a></div></td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#f6f6f6; color:black;"> </span> Independent</div></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>
<p>Imperial rule by Europeans would continue until after the conclusion of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, when almost all remaining colonial territories gradually obtained formal independence. <a href="/wiki/African_independence_movements" title="African independence movements">Independence movements in Africa</a> gained momentum following World War II, which left the major European powers weakened. In 1951, <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>, a former Italian colony, gained independence. In 1956, <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a> won their independence from France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a> followed suit the next year (March 1957),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> becoming the first of the sub-Saharan colonies to be granted independence. Most of the rest of the continent became independent over the next decade.
</p><p>Portugal's overseas presence in <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a> (most notably in <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Angola" title="Portuguese Angola">Angola</a>, Cape Verde, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Mozambique" title="Portuguese Mozambique">Mozambique</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Guinea" title="Portuguese Guinea">Guinea-Bissau</a> and São Tomé and Príncipe) lasted from the 16th century to 1975, after the <a href="/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal)" title="Estado Novo (Portugal)">Estado Novo</a> regime was overthrown in <a href="/wiki/Carnation_Revolution" title="Carnation Revolution">a military coup in Lisbon</a>. <a href="/wiki/Rhodesia" title="Rhodesia">Rhodesia</a> <a href="/wiki/Rhodesia%27s_Unilateral_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Rhodesia's Unilateral Declaration of Independence">unilaterally declared independence</a> from the United Kingdom in 1965, under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_minority_rule" title="White minority rule">white minority</a> government of <a href="/wiki/Ian_Smith" title="Ian Smith">Ian Smith</a>, but was not internationally recognized as an independent state (as <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>) until 1980, when black nationalists gained power after a <a href="/wiki/Rhodesian_Bush_War" title="Rhodesian Bush War">bitter guerrilla war</a>. Although South Africa was one of the first African countries to gain independence, the state remained under the control of the country's white minority through a system of racial segregation known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Africa_under_apartheid" title="South Africa under apartheid">apartheid</a> until 1994.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-colonial_Africa">Post-colonial Africa</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Decolonisation_of_Africa" title="Decolonisation of Africa">Decolonisation of Africa</a></div>
<p>Today, Africa contains 54 sovereign countries, most of which have borders that were drawn during the era of European colonialism. Since independence, African states have frequently been hampered by instability, corruption, violence, and authoritarianism. The vast majority of African states are republics that operate under some form of the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a> of rule. However, few of them have been able to sustain democratic governments on a permanent basis—per the criteria laid out by Lührmann et al. (2018), only <a href="/wiki/Botswana" title="Botswana">Botswana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">Mauritius</a> have been consistently democratic for the entirety of their post-colonial history. Most African countries have experienced several <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coups</a>, and/or periods of <a href="/wiki/Military_dictatorship" title="Military dictatorship">military dictatorship</a>.
