Between 1990 and 2018, though, the continent as a whole has trended towards more democratic governance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>Upon independence an overwhelming majority of Africans lived in <a href="/wiki/Extreme_poverty" title="Extreme poverty">extreme poverty</a>. The continent suffered from the lack of infrastructural or industrial development under colonial rule, along with political instability. With limited financial resources or access to global markets, relatively stable countries such as <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">Kenya</a> still experienced only very slow economic development. Only a handful of African countries succeeded in obtaining rapid economic growth prior to 1990. Exceptions include Libya and Equatorial Guinea, both of which possess large oil reserves.
</p><p>Instability throughout the continent after decolonization resulted primarily from <a href="/wiki/Institutional_racism" title="Institutional racism">marginalization of ethnic groups</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Political_corruption" title="Political corruption">corruption</a>. In pursuit of personal <a href="/wiki/Divide_and_rule" title="Divide and rule">political gain</a>, many leaders deliberately promoted ethnic conflicts, some of which had originated during the colonial period, such as from the grouping of multiple unrelated ethnic groups into a single colony, the splitting of a distinct ethnic group between multiple colonies, or existing conflicts being exacerbated by colonial rule (for instance, the preferential treatment given to ethnic <a href="/wiki/Hutu" title="Hutu">Hutus</a> over <a href="/wiki/Tutsi" title="Tutsi">Tutsis</a> in Rwanda during German and Belgian rule).
</p><p>Faced with increasingly frequent and severe violence, military rule was widely accepted by the population of many countries as means to maintain order, and during the 1970s and 1980s a majority of African countries were controlled by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_dictatorships" title="Military dictatorships">military dictatorships</a>. Territorial disputes between nations and rebellions by groups seeking independence were also common in independent African states. The most devastating of these was the <a href="/wiki/Nigerian_Civil_War" title="Nigerian Civil War">Nigerian Civil War</a>, fought between government forces and an <a href="/wiki/Igbo_people" title="Igbo people">Igbo</a> <a href="/wiki/Biafra" title="Biafra">separatist republic</a>, which resulted in a famine that killed 1-2 million people. Two civil wars in Sudan, <a href="/wiki/First_Sudanese_Civil_War" title="First Sudanese Civil War">the first</a> lasting from 1955 to 1972 and <a href="/wiki/Second_Sudanese_Civil_War" title="Second Sudanese Civil War">the second</a> from 1983 to 2005 collectively killed around 3 million. Both were fought primarily on ethnic and religious lines.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> conflicts between the United States and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> also contributed to instability. Both the Soviet Union and the United States offered considerable incentives to African political and military leaders who aligned themselves with the superpowers' foreign policy. As an example, during the <a href="/wiki/Angolan_Civil_War" title="Angolan Civil War">Angolan Civil War</a>, the Soviet and Cuban aligned <a href="/wiki/MPLA" title="MPLA">MPLA</a> and the American aligned <a href="/wiki/UNITA" title="UNITA">UNITA</a> received the vast majority of their military and political support from these countries. Many African countries became highly dependent on foreign aid. The sudden loss of both Soviet and American aid at the end of the Cold War and <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">fall of the USSR</a> resulted in severe economic and political turmoil in the countries most dependent on foreign support.
</p><p>There was a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1983%E2%80%9385_famine_in_Ethiopia" title="1983–85 famine in Ethiopia">major famine in Ethiopia</a> between 1983 and 1985, killing up to 1.2 million people, which most historians attribute primarily to the forced relocation of farmworkers and seizure of grain by communist <a href="/wiki/Derg" title="Derg">Derg</a> government, further exacerbated by the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Civil_War" title="Ethiopian Civil War">civil war</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> In 1994 a <a href="/wiki/Rwandan_genocide" title="Rwandan genocide">genocide in Rwanda</a> resulted in up to 800,000 deaths, added to <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes_refugee_crisis" title="Great Lakes refugee crisis">a severe refugee crisis</a> and fueled the rise of militia groups in neighboring countries. This contributed to the outbreak of the <a href="/wiki/First_Congo_War" title="First Congo War">first</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Congo_War" title="Second Congo War">second</a> Congo Wars, which were the most devastating military conflicts in modern Africa, with up to 5.5 million deaths,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> making it by far the deadliest conflict in modern African history and one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_by_death_toll" title="List of wars by death toll">costliest wars in human history</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 318.66666666667px"><div style="width: 318.66666666667px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 316.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:African_nations_order_of_independence_1950-1993.gif" title="An animated map shows the order of independence of African nations, 1950–2011"><img alt="An animated map shows the order of independence of African nations, 1950–2011" data-file-height="355" data-file-width="450" decoding="async" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4a/African_nations_order_of_independence_1950-1993.gif" width="317"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>An animated map shows the order of <a href="/wiki/Decolonisation_of_Africa" title="Decolonisation of Africa">independence of African nations</a>, 1950–2011
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 288.66666666667px"><div style="width: 288.66666666667px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 286.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Africa%E2%80%99s_wars_and_conflicts,_1980%E2%80%9396.svg" title="Africa's wars and conflicts, 1980–96   Major Wars/Conflict (100,000 + Casualties)   Minor Wars/Conflict   Other Conflicts"><img alt="Africa's wars and conflicts, 1980–96   Major Wars/Conflict (100,000 + Casualties)   Minor Wars/Conflict   Other Conflicts" data-file-height="698" data-file-width="801" decoding="async" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Africa%E2%80%99s_wars_and_conflicts%2C_1980%E2%80%9396.svg/430px-Africa%E2%80%99s_wars_and_conflicts%2C_1980%E2%80%9396.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Africa%E2%80%99s_wars_and_conflicts%2C_1980%E2%80%9396.svg/646px-Africa%E2%80%99s_wars_and_conflicts%2C_1980%E2%80%9396.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Africa%E2%80%99s_wars_and_conflicts%2C_1980%E2%80%9396.svg/861px-Africa%E2%80%99s_wars_and_conflicts%2C_1980%E2%80%9396.svg.png 2x" width="287"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
Africa's wars and conflicts, 1980–96<br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#cc4c02; color:black;"> </span> Major Wars/Conflict (100,000 + Casualties)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fe9929; color:black;"> </span> Minor Wars/Conflict</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fed98e; color:black;"> </span> Other Conflicts</div>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 208px"><div style="width: 208px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 206px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Political_Map_of_Africa.svg" title="Political map of Africa in 2021"><img alt="Political map of Africa in 2021" data-file-height="820" data-file-width="676" decoding="async" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Political_Map_of_Africa.svg/309px-Political_Map_of_Africa.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Political_Map_of_Africa.svg/464px-Political_Map_of_Africa.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Political_Map_of_Africa.svg/618px-Political_Map_of_Africa.svg.png 2x" width="206"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Political map of Africa in 2021
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<p>Various conflicts between various insurgent groups and governments continue. Since 2003 there has been an ongoing <a href="/wiki/War_in_Darfur" title="War in Darfur">conflict in Darfur</a> (Sudan) which peaked in intensity from 2003 to 2005 with notable spikes in violence in 2007 and 2013–15, killing around 300,000 people total. The <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Boko_Haram_Insurgency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Boko Haram Insurgency (page does not exist)">Boko Haram Insurgency</a> primarily within Nigeria (with considerable fighting in Niger, Chad, and Cameroon as well) has killed around 350,000 people since 2009. Most African conflicts have been reduced to low-intensity conflicts as of 2022. However, the <a href="/wiki/Tigray_War" title="Tigray War">Tigray War</a> which began in 2020 has killed an estimated 300,000-500,000 people, primarily due to <a href="/wiki/Famine_in_the_Tigray_War" title="Famine in the Tigray War">famine</a>.
</p><p>Overall though, violence across Africa has greatly declined in the in the 21st century, with the end of civil wars in <a href="/wiki/Angolan_Civil_War" title="Angolan Civil War">Angola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Leone_Civil_War" title="Sierra Leone Civil War">Sierra Leone</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Algerian_Civil_War" title="Algerian Civil War">Algeria</a> in 2002, <a href="/wiki/Second_Liberian_Civil_War" title="Second Liberian Civil War">Liberia</a> in 2003, and <a href="/wiki/Second_Sudanese_Civil_War" title="Second Sudanese Civil War">Sudan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Burundian_Civil_War" title="Burundian Civil War">Burundi</a> in 2005. The Second Congo War, which involved 9 countries and several insurgent groups, ended in 2003. This decline in violence coincided with many countries abandoning communist-style command economies and opening up for market reforms, which over the course of the 1990s and 2000s promoted the establishment of permanent, peaceful trade between neighboring countries (see <a href="/wiki/Capitalist_peace" title="Capitalist peace">Capitalist peace</a>).
</p><p>Improved stability and economic reforms have led to a great increase in foreign investment into many African nations, mainly from China,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Africa_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-Africa-124">[124]</a></sup> which further spurred economic growth. Between 2000 and 2014, annual GDP growth in Sub-Saharan Africa averaged 5.02%, doubling its total GDP from $811 Billion to $1.63 Trillion (Constant 2015 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USD" title="USD">USD</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> North Africa experienced comparable growth rates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> A significant part of this growth can also be attributed to the facilitated diffusion of information technologies and specifically the mobile telephone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> While several individuals countries have maintained high growth rates, since 2014 overall growth has considerably slowed, primarily as a result of falling commodity prices, continued lack of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrialization" title="Industrialization">industrialization</a>, and epidemics of <a href="/wiki/Western_African_Ebola_virus_epidemic" title="Western African Ebola virus epidemic">Ebola</a> and <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Africa" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Africa">COVID-19</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Geology.2C_geography.2C_ecology_and_environment"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology,_geography,_ecology_and_environment">Geology, geography, ecology and environment</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Africa" title="Geography of Africa">Geography of Africa</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Topography_of_africa.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2100" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="284" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Topography_of_africa.png/260px-Topography_of_africa.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Topography_of_africa.png/390px-Topography_of_africa.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Topography_of_africa.png/520px-Topography_of_africa.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Topography_of_africa.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Topography of Africa</div></div></div>
<p>Africa is the largest of the three great southward projections from the largest landmass of the Earth. Separated from Europe by the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>, it is joined to Asia at its northeast extremity by the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Isthmus of Suez</a> (transected by the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a>), 163 km (101 mi) wide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Geopolitics" title="Geopolitics">Geopolitically</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a> east of the Suez Canal is often considered part of Africa, as well.)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>The coastline is 26,000 km (16,000 mi) long, and the absence of deep indentations of the shore is illustrated by the fact that Europe, which covers only 10,400,000 km<sup>2</sup> (4,000,000 sq mi) – about a third of the surface of Africa – has a coastline of 32,000 km (20,000 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-MW-132">[132]</a></sup> From the most northerly point, <a href="/wiki/Ras_ben_Sakka" title="Ras ben Sakka">Ras ben Sakka</a> in Tunisia (37°21' N), to the most southerly point, <a href="/wiki/Cape_Agulhas" title="Cape Agulhas">Cape Agulhas</a> in South Africa (34°51'15" S), is a distance of approximately 8,000 km (5,000 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cap-Vert" title="Cap-Vert">Cape Verde</a>, 17°33'22" W, the westernmost point, is a distance of approximately 7,400 km (4,600 mi) to <a href="/wiki/Ras_Hafun" title="Ras Hafun">Ras Hafun</a>, 51°27'52" E, the most easterly projection that neighbours <a href="/wiki/Cape_Guardafui" title="Cape Guardafui">Cape Guardafui</a>, the tip of the Horn of Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW_132-1"><a href="#cite_note-MW-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>Africa's largest country is <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, and its smallest country is <a href="/wiki/Seychelles" title="Seychelles">Seychelles</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> off the east coast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoare_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hoare-134">[134]</a></sup> The smallest nation on the continental mainland is <a href="/wiki/The_Gambia" title="The Gambia">The Gambia</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="African_plate">African plate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Motion_of_Nubia_Plate.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="260" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Motion_of_Nubia_Plate.gif/260px-Motion_of_Nubia_Plate.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b4/Motion_of_Nubia_Plate.gif 1.5x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Motion_of_Nubia_Plate.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Today, the African Plate is moving over Earth's surface at a speed of 0.292° ± 0.007° per million years, relative to the "average" Earth (NNR-MORVEL56)</div></div></div>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/African_Plate" title="African Plate">African Plate</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=African_Plate&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/African_Plate" title="African Plate">African Plate</a> is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_tectonic_plates#Major_plates" title="List of tectonic plates">major tectonic plate</a> straddling the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">Equator</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Prime_meridian" title="Prime meridian">prime meridian</a>. It includes much of the <a href="/wiki/Continent" title="Continent">continent</a> of Africa, as well as oceanic crust which lies between the continent and various surrounding ocean ridges. Between <span class="nourlexpansion plainlinks" style="white-space:nowrap;"><a class="external text" href="http://tools.wmflabs.org/timescale/?Ma=60">60</a> million years ago</span> and <span class="nourlexpansion plainlinks" style="white-space:nowrap;"><a class="external text" href="http://tools.wmflabs.org/timescale/?Ma=10">10</a> million years ago</span>, the <a href="/wiki/Somali_Plate" title="Somali Plate">Somali Plate</a> began <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rift_(geology)" title="Rift (geology)">rifting</a> from the African Plate along the <a href="/wiki/East_African_Rift" title="East African Rift">East African Rift</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> Since the continent of Africa consists of crust from both the African and the Somali plates, some literature refers to the African Plate as the Nubian Plate to distinguish it from the continent as a whole.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
The <a href="/wiki/Zagros_Mountains" title="Zagros Mountains">Zagros Mountains</a> of Iran and the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_Plateau" title="Anatolian Plateau">Anatolian Plateau</a> of Turkey mark where the African Plate collided with Eurasia.</div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Africa" title="Climate of Africa">Climate of Africa</a></div>
<p>The climate of Africa ranges from <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical</a> to <a href="/wiki/Subarctic_climate" title="Subarctic climate">subarctic</a> on its highest peaks. Its northern half is primarily <a href="/wiki/Desert" title="Desert">desert</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Arid" title="Arid">arid</a>, while its central and southern areas contain both <a href="/wiki/Savanna" title="Savanna">savanna</a> plains and dense <a href="/wiki/Jungle" title="Jungle">jungle</a> (<a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforest</a>) regions. In between, there is a convergence, where vegetation patterns such as <a href="/wiki/Sahel" title="Sahel">sahel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a> dominate. Africa is the hottest continent on Earth and 60% of the entire land surface consists of drylands and deserts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-environmentalatlas_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-environmentalatlas-137">[137]</a></sup> The record for the highest-ever recorded temperature, in <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a> in 1922 (58 °C (136 °F)), was discredited in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newRecord_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-newRecord-138">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ecology_and_biodiversity">Ecology and biodiversity</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vegetation_Africa.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1165" data-file-width="1295" decoding="async" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Vegetation_Africa.png/260px-Vegetation_Africa.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Vegetation_Africa.png/390px-Vegetation_Africa.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Vegetation_Africa.png/520px-Vegetation_Africa.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vegetation_Africa.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The main biomes in Africa.</div></div></div>
<p>Africa has over 3,000 <a href="/wiki/Protected_area" title="Protected area">protected areas</a>, with 198 marine protected areas, 50 biosphere reserves, and 80 wetlands reserves. Significant habitat destruction, increases in human population and poaching are reducing Africa's biological diversity and <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable land</a>. Human encroachment, civil unrest and the introduction of non-native species threaten biodiversity in Africa. This has been exacerbated by administrative problems, inadequate personnel and funding problems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-environmentalatlas_137-1"><a href="#cite_note-environmentalatlas-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">Deforestation</a> is affecting Africa at twice the world rate, according to the United Nations Environment Programme (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNEP" title="UNEP">UNEP</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> According to the University of Pennsylvania African Studies Center, 31% of Africa's pasture lands and 19% of its forests and woodlands are classified as degraded, and Africa is losing over four million hectares of forest per year, which is twice the average deforestation rate for the rest of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-environmentalatlas_137-2"><a href="#cite_note-environmentalatlas-137">[137]</a></sup> Some sources claim that approximately 90% of the original, virgin forests in West Africa have been destroyed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Over 90% of <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">Madagascar</a>'s original forests have been destroyed since the arrival of humans 2000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> About 65% of Africa's agricultural land suffers from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soil_degradation" title="Soil degradation">soil degradation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Afrotropical_realm" title="Afrotropical realm">Afrotropical realm</a> and <a href="/wiki/Palearctic_realm" title="Palearctic realm">Palearctic realm</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_issues">Environmental issues</span></h3>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Africa" title="Environmental issues in Africa">Environmental issues in Africa</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Environmental_issues_in_Africa&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
Environmental issues can be defined as the harmful effects of any human activity on the environment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> African environmental issues are caused by <a href="/wiki/Human_impact_on_the_environment" title="Human impact on the environment">anthropogenic</a> effects on the African <a href="/wiki/Natural_environment" title="Natural environment">natural environment</a> and have major impacts on humans and nearly all forms of <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemic life</a>. Issues include for example <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_Africa" title="Deforestation in Africa">deforestation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soil_retrogression_and_degradation" title="Soil retrogression and degradation">soil degradation</a>, air pollution, water pollution, garbage pollution<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Africa" title="Climate change in Africa">climate change</a> and <a href="/wiki/Water_scarcity_in_Africa" title="Water scarcity in Africa">water scarcity</a> (resulting in problems with access to safe <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Water supply and sanitation in Sub-Saharan Africa">water supply and sanitation</a>). Nearly all of Africa's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Environmental_problems" title="Environmental problems">environmental problems</a> are <a href="/wiki/Geography" title="Geography">geographically</a> variable and human induced.</div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water">Water</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Africa_Precipitation_Map.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Africa_Precipitation_Map.svg/220px-Africa_Precipitation_Map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Africa_Precipitation_Map.svg/330px-Africa_Precipitation_Map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Africa_Precipitation_Map.svg/440px-Africa_Precipitation_Map.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Africa_Precipitation_Map.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Africa Water Precipitation</div></div></div>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Water_in_Africa" title="Water in Africa">Water in Africa</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Water_in_Africa&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<p><a href="/wiki/Water_in_Africa" title="Water in Africa">Water in Africa</a> is an important issue encompassing the sources, distribution and economic uses of the <a href="/wiki/Water_resources" title="Water resources">water resources</a> on the continent. Overall, Africa has about 9% of the world's <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a> resources and 16% of the <a href="/wiki/World_population" title="World population">world's population</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:1_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:1-146">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:0_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:0-147">[147]</a></sup> Among its rivers are the Congo, Nile, Zambezi, Niger and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Victoria" title="Lake Victoria">Lake Victoria</a>, considered the world’s second largest lake. Yet the continent is the second driest in the world, with millions of Africans still suffering from water shortages throughout the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:7_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:7-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
These shortages are attributed to problems of uneven distribution, population boom and poor management of existing supplies. Sometimes there are smaller numbers of people residing where there is large amount of water. For example, 30 percent of the continent's water lies in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congo_basin" title="Congo basin">Congo basin</a> inhabited by only 10 percent of Africa’s population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:8_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:8-149">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:7_148-1"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:7-148">[148]</a></sup> There is significant variation in the rainfall patterns observed in different places and time. There is also high evaporation rates in some parts of the region resulting in lower percentages of precipitation in such places.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:9_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:9-150">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:8_149-1"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:8-149">[149]</a></sup> However, there is very significant inter-and intra-annual variability of all <a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">climate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Water_resources" title="Water resources">water resources</a> characteristics, so while some regions have sufficient water,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:0_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:0-147">[147]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a> faces numerous water-related challenges that constrain <a href="/wiki/Economic_growth" title="Economic growth">economic growth</a> and threaten the livelihoods of its people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:0_147-2"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:0-147">[147]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Africa" title="Agriculture in Africa">African agriculture</a> is mostly based on <a href="/wiki/Rain" title="Rain">rain</a>-fed farming, and less than 10% of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cultivated_land" title="Cultivated land">cultivated</a> land in the continent is <a href="/wiki/Irrigation" title="Irrigation">irrigated</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:1_146-1"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:1-146">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:0_147-3"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:0-147">[147]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Effects_of_climate_change" title="Effects of climate change">impact of climate change</a> and variability is thus very pronounced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:0_147-4"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:0-147">[147]</a></sup> The main source of <a href="/wiki/Electricity" title="Electricity">electricity</a> is <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a>, which contributes significantly to the current installed capacity for energy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:0_147-5"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:0-147">[147]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kainji_Dam" title="Kainji Dam">Kainji Dam</a> is a typical hydropower resource generating electricity for all the large cities in <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> as well as their neighbouring country, <a href="/wiki/Niger" title="Niger">Niger</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> Hence, the continuous investment in the last decade, which has increased the amount of power generated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_in_Africa_:0_147-6"><a href="#cite_note-Water_in_Africa_:0-147">[147]</a></sup></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate_change">Climate change</span></h3>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Africa" title="Climate change in Africa">Climate change in Africa</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Climate_change_in_Africa&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<p><a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Africa" title="Climate change in Africa">Climate change in Africa</a> is an increasingly serious threat in Africa which is among the most <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_vulnerability" title="Climate change vulnerability">vulnerable</a> continents to the <a href="/wiki/Effects_of_climate_change" title="Effects of climate change">effects of climate change</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_:10_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_:10-153">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_:4_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_:4-154">[154]</a></sup> Some sources even classify Africa as "the most vulnerable continent on Earth".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_:7_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_:7-155">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> This vulnerability is driven by a range of factors that include weak <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_adaptation" title="Climate change adaptation">adaptive capacity</a>, high dependence on ecosystem goods for livelihoods, and less developed agricultural production systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> The risks of climate change on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agricultural_production" title="Agricultural production">agricultural production</a>, <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">food security</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_resources" title="Water resources">water resources</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem_service" title="Ecosystem service">ecosystem services</a> will likely have increasingly severe consequences on lives and <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_development" title="Sustainable development">sustainable development</a> prospects in Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> With high confidence, it was projected by the <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmental_Panel_on_Climate_Change" title="Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change">IPCC</a> in 2007 that in many African countries and regions, agricultural production and <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">food security</a> would probably be severely compromised by climate change and climate variability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_IPCC_4th_assessment_e_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_IPCC_4th_assessment_e-159">[159]</a></sup> Managing this risk requires an integration of <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_mitigation" title="Climate change mitigation">mitigation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_adaptation" title="Climate change adaptation">adaptation strategies</a> in the management of ecosystem goods and services, and the agriculture production systems in Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
Over the coming decades, warming from climate change is expected across almost all the Earth's surface, and global mean rainfall will increase.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_Global_Warming_of_1.5_ºC_—_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_Global_Warming_of_1.5_ºC_—-161">[161]</a></sup> Currently, Africa is warming faster than the rest of the world on average. Large portions of the continent may become uninhabitable as a result of the rapid effects of climate change, which would have disastrous effects on human health, food security, and poverty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup>Regional effects on rainfall in the tropics are expected to be much more spatially variable and the sign of change at any one location is often less certain, although changes are expected. Consistent with this, observed <a href="/wiki/Instrumental_temperature_record" title="Instrumental temperature record">surface temperatures</a> have generally increased over Africa since the late 19th century to the early 21st century by about  1 °C, but locally as much as 3 °C for minimum temperature in the Sahel at the end of the dry season.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_:14_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_:14-165">[165]</a></sup> Observed precipitation trends indicate spatial and temporal discrepancies as expected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_:11_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_:11-166">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_:10_153-1"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_:10-153">[153]</a></sup> The observed changes in temperature and <a href="/wiki/Precipitation" title="Precipitation">precipitation</a> vary regionally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_:15_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_:15-167">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Africa_:11_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Africa_:11-166">[166]</a></sup></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fauna">Fauna</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Africa" title="Fauna of Africa">Fauna of Africa</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zebras,_Serengeti_savana_plains,_Tanzania.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="552" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Zebras%2C_Serengeti_savana_plains%2C_Tanzania.jpg/220px-Zebras%2C_Serengeti_savana_plains%2C_Tanzania.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Zebras%2C_Serengeti_savana_plains%2C_Tanzania.jpg/330px-Zebras%2C_Serengeti_savana_plains%2C_Tanzania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Zebras%2C_Serengeti_savana_plains%2C_Tanzania.jpg/440px-Zebras%2C_Serengeti_savana_plains%2C_Tanzania.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zebras,_Serengeti_savana_plains,_Tanzania.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Savanna at <a href="/wiki/Ngorongoro_Conservation_Area" title="Ngorongoro Conservation Area">Ngorongoro Conservation Area</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tanzania" title="Tanzania">Tanzania</a></div></div></div>
<p>Africa boasts perhaps the world's largest combination of density and "range of freedom" of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wild_animal" title="Wild animal">wild animal</a> populations and diversity, with wild populations of large <a href="/wiki/Carnivore" title="Carnivore">carnivores</a> (such as lions, <a href="/wiki/Hyena" title="Hyena">hyenas</a>, and cheetahs) and <a href="/wiki/Herbivore" title="Herbivore">herbivores</a> (such as <a href="/wiki/African_buffalo" title="African buffalo">buffalo</a>, elephants, camels, and giraffes) ranging freely on primarily open non-private plains. It is also home to a variety of "jungle" animals including snakes and <a href="/wiki/Primate" title="Primate">primates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aquatic_ecosystem" title="Aquatic ecosystem">aquatic life</a> such as crocodiles and <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibians</a>. In addition, Africa has the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Megafauna" title="Megafauna">megafauna</a> species, as it was least affected by the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary_extinction_event#The_Pleistocene_or_Ice_Age_extinction_event" title="Quaternary extinction event">extinction of the Pleistocene megafauna</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Africa_by_country" title="List of political parties in Africa by country">List of political parties in Africa by country</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="African_Union">African Union</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Regions_of_the_African_Union.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Regions_of_the_African_Union.png/220px-Regions_of_the_African_Union.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Regions_of_the_African_Union.png/330px-Regions_of_the_African_Union.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Regions_of_the_African_Union.png/440px-Regions_of_the_African_Union.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Regions_of_the_African_Union.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Regions_of_the_African_Union" title="Regions of the African Union">Regions of the African Union</a>:<br/> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#DAA520; color:black;border:1px solid darkgray;"> <b>Northern Region</b>  (Sahara) </span>, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#87CEEB; color:black;border:1px solid darkgray;"> <b>Southern Region</b>  (Kalahari) </span>, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#90EE90; color:black;border:1px solid darkgray;"> <b>Eastern Region</b>  (Nile) </span>, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#FA8072; color:black;border:1px solid darkgray;"> <b>Western Regions A and B</b>  (Niger and Volta Niger) </span>, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#B88FFF; color:black;border:1px solid darkgray;"> <b>Central Region</b> (Congo)  </span></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a> (AU) is a <a href="/wiki/Continental_union" title="Continental union">continental union</a> consisting of 55 <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_African_Union" title="Member states of the African Union">member states</a>. The union was formed, with <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a>, as its headquarters, on 26 June 2001. The union was officially established on 9 July 2002<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-African_Union_2002_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-African_Union_2002-168">[168]</a></sup> as a successor to the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_African_Unity" title="Organisation of African Unity">Organisation of African Unity</a> (OAU). In July 2004, the African Union's <a href="/wiki/Pan-African_Parliament" title="Pan-African Parliament">Pan-African Parliament</a> (PAP) was relocated to <a href="/wiki/Midrand" title="Midrand">Midrand</a>, in South Africa, but the <a href="/wiki/African_Commission_on_Human_and_Peoples%27_Rights" title="African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights">African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights</a> remained in Addis Ababa.
</p><p>The African Union, not to be confused with the <a href="/wiki/African_Union_Commission" title="African Union Commission">AU Commission</a>, is formed by the <a href="/wiki/Constitutive_Act_of_the_African_Union" title="Constitutive Act of the African Union">Constitutive Act of the African Union</a>, which aims to transform the <a href="/wiki/African_Economic_Community" title="African Economic Community">African Economic Community</a>, a federated commonwealth, into a state under established international conventions. The African Union has a parliamentary government, known as the <a href="/wiki/Assembly_of_the_African_Union" title="Assembly of the African Union">African Union Government</a>, consisting of legislative, judicial and executive organs. It is led by the African Union President and Head of State, who is also the President of the <a href="/wiki/Pan-African_Parliament" title="Pan-African Parliament">Pan-African Parliament</a>. A person becomes AU President by being elected to the PAP, and subsequently gaining majority support in the PAP. The powers and authority of the President of the African Parliament derive from the Constitutive Act and the <a href="/wiki/Pan-African_Parliament" title="Pan-African Parliament">Protocol of the Pan-African Parliament</a>, as well as the inheritance of presidential authority stipulated by African treaties and by international treaties, including those subordinating the Secretary General of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_African_Unity" title="Organisation of African Unity">OAU</a> Secretariat (AU Commission) to the PAP. The government of the AU consists of all-union, regional, state, and municipal authorities, as well as hundreds of institutions, that together manage the day-to-day affairs of the institution.
</p><p>Extensive human rights abuses still occur in several parts of Africa, often under the oversight of the state. Most of such violations occur for political reasons, often as a side effect of civil war. Countries where major human rights violations have been reported in recent times include the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo" title="Democratic Republic of the Congo">Democratic Republic of the Congo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Leone" title="Sierra Leone">Sierra Leone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ivory_Coast" title="Ivory Coast">Ivory Coast</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Boundary_conflicts">Boundary conflicts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Berlin_Conference_of_1884%E2%80%931885" title="The Berlin Conference of 1884–1885">The Berlin Conference of 1884–1885</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_conflicts_in_Africa" title="List of conflicts in Africa">List of conflicts in Africa</a></div>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Africa#Post-colonial" title="Military history of Africa">Military history of Africa § Post-colonial</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_Africa&amp;action=edit#Post-colonial">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
African states have made great efforts to respect interstate borders as inviolate for a long time. For example, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organization_of_African_Unity" title="Organization of African Unity">Organization of African Unity</a> (OAU), which was established in 1963 and replaced by the <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a> in 2002, set the respect for the territorial integrity of each state as one of its principles in OAU Charter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> Indeed, compared with the formation of European states, there have been fewer interstate conflicts in Africa for changing the borders, which has influenced the state formation there and has enabled some states to survive that might have been defeated and absorbed by others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Military_history_of_Africa_Herbst_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-Military_history_of_Africa_Herbst-170">[170]</a></sup> Yet interstate conflicts have played out by support for proxy armies or rebel movements. Many states have experienced civil wars: including Rwanda, Sudan, Angola, Sierra Leone, Congo, Liberia, Ethiopia and Somalia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Africa" title="Economy of Africa">Economy of Africa</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_African_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of African countries by GDP (nominal)">List of African countries by GDP (nominal)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_African_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of African countries by GDP (PPP)">List of African countries by GDP (PPP)</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_African_Union" title="Economy of the African Union">Economy of the African Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RECs_of_the_AEC.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="260" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/RECs_of_the_AEC.svg/260px-RECs_of_the_AEC.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/RECs_of_the_AEC.svg/390px-RECs_of_the_AEC.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/RECs_of_the_AEC.svg/520px-RECs_of_the_AEC.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RECs_of_the_AEC.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of the <a href="/wiki/African_Economic_Community" title="African Economic Community">African Economic Community</a>. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#691717; color:white;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Community_of_Sahel-Saharan_States" title="Community of Sahel-Saharan States">CEN-SAD</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#4F4FB1; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Common_Market_for_Eastern_and_Southern_Africa" title="Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa">COMESA</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#E88356; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/East_African_Community" title="East African Community">EAC</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#272759; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Economic_Community_of_Central_African_States" title="Economic Community of Central African States">ECCAS</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#C43C7F; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Economic_Community_of_West_African_States" title="Economic Community of West African States">ECOWAS</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#4DB34D; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmental_Authority_on_Development" title="Intergovernmental Authority on Development">IGAD</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#D22E2E; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Southern_African_Development_Community" title="Southern African Development Community">SADC</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#7E8000; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Arab_Maghreb_Union" title="Arab Maghreb Union">UMA</a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Although it has abundant <a href="/wiki/Natural_resource" title="Natural resource">natural resources</a>, Africa remains the world's poorest and <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">least-developed</a> continent (other than <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>), the result of a variety of causes that may include <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">corrupt governments</a> that have often committed serious <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_rights_violations" title="Human rights violations">human rights violations</a>, failed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_planning" title="Central planning">central planning</a>, high levels of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illiteracy" title="Illiteracy">illiteracy</a>, low self-esteem, lack of access to foreign capital, legacies of colonialism, the slave trade, and the Cold War, and frequent tribal and military conflict (ranging from <a href="/wiki/Guerrilla_warfare" title="Guerrilla warfare">guerrilla warfare</a> to <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> Its total nominal GDP remains behind that of the United States, China, Japan, Germany, the United Kingdom, India and France. According to the United Nations' Human Development Report in 2003, the bottom 24 ranked nations (151st to 175th) were all African.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Africa" title="Poverty in Africa">Poverty</a>, illiteracy, <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> and inadequate water supply and sanitation, as well as poor health, affect a large proportion of the people who reside in the African continent. In August 2008, the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> announced revised global poverty estimates based on a new international poverty line of $1.25 per day (versus the previous measure of $1.00). 81% of the <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a> population was living on less than $2.50 (PPP) per day in 2005, compared with 86% for India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sub-Saharan Africa is the least successful region of the world in reducing poverty ($1.25 per day); some 50% of <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Africa" title="Poverty in Africa">the population living in poverty</a> in 1981 (200 million people), a figure that rose to 58% in 1996 before dropping to 50% in 2005 (380 million people). The average poor person in sub-Saharan Africa is estimated to live on only 70 cents per day, and was poorer in 2003 than in 1973,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> indicating increasing poverty in some areas. Some of it is attributed to unsuccessful economic liberalization programmes spearheaded by foreign companies and governments, but other studies have cited bad domestic government policies more than external factors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>Africa is now at risk of being in debt once again, particularly in Sub-Saharan African countries. The last debt crisis in 2005 was resolved with help from the heavily indebted poor countries scheme (HIPC). The HIPC resulted in some positive and negative effects on the economy in Africa. About ten years after the 2005 debt crisis in Sub-Saharan Africa was resolved, Zambia fell back into debt. A small reason was due to the fall in copper prices in 2011, but the bigger reason was that a large amount of the money Zambia borrowed was wasted or pocketed by the elite.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1995 to 2005, Africa's rate of economic growth increased, averaging 5% in 2005. Some countries experienced still higher growth rates, notably <a href="/wiki/Angola" title="Angola">Angola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Equatorial_Guinea" title="Equatorial Guinea">Equatorial Guinea</a>, all of which had recently begun extracting their petroleum reserves or had expanded their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_extraction" title="Oil extraction">oil extraction</a> capacity.
</p><p>In a recently published analysis based on <a href="/wiki/World_Values_Survey" title="World Values Survey">World Values Survey</a> data, the Austrian political scientist <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Arno_Tausch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Arno Tausch (page does not exist)">Arno Tausch</a> maintained that several African countries, most notably <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a>, perform quite well on scales of mass support for democracy and the <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>

<td align="left"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Flag_of_Nigeria.svg/23px-Flag_of_Nigeria.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Flag_of_Nigeria.svg/35px-Flag_of_Nigeria.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Flag_of_Nigeria.svg/46px-Flag_of_Nigeria.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a></td>

<td>220,533</td>
<td>2016
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<p>Tausch's global value comparison based on the <a href="/wiki/World_Values_Survey" title="World Values Survey">World Values Survey</a> derived the following factor analytical scales: 1. The non-violent and law-abiding society 2. Democracy movement 3. Climate of personal non-violence 4. Trust in institutions 5. Happiness, good health 6. No redistributive religious fundamentalism 7. Accepting the market 8. Feminism 9. Involvement in politics 10. Optimism and engagement 11. No welfare mentality, acceptancy of the Calvinist work ethics. The spread in the performance of African countries with complete data, Tausch concluded "is really amazing". While one should be especially hopeful about the development of future democracy and the market economy in <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a>, the article suggests pessimistic tendencies for <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, and especially for Africa's leading economy, South Africa. High <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Human_Inequality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Human Inequality (page does not exist)">Human Inequality</a>, as measured by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNDP" title="UNDP">UNDP</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Report" title="Human Development Report">Human Development Report</a>'s <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Index_of_Human_Inequality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Index of Human Inequality (page does not exist)">Index of Human Inequality</a>, further impairs the development of <a href="/wiki/Human_security" title="Human security">human security</a>. Tausch also maintains that the certain recent optimism, corresponding to economic and human rights data, emerging from Africa, is reflected in the development of a <a href="/wiki/Civil_society" title="Civil society">civil society</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:African_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita_in_2020.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4795" data-file-width="4800" decoding="async" height="260" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/African_countries_by_GDP_%28PPP%29_per_capita_in_2020.png/260px-African_countries_by_GDP_%28PPP%29_per_capita_in_2020.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/African_countries_by_GDP_%28PPP%29_per_capita_in_2020.png/390px-African_countries_by_GDP_%28PPP%29_per_capita_in_2020.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/African_countries_by_GDP_%28PPP%29_per_capita_in_2020.png/520px-African_countries_by_GDP_%28PPP%29_per_capita_in_2020.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:African_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita_in_2020.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>African countries by GDP (PPP) per capita in 2020</div></div></div>
<p>The continent is believed to hold 90% of the world's <a href="/wiki/Cobalt" title="Cobalt">cobalt</a>, 90% of its <a href="/wiki/Platinum" title="Platinum">platinum</a>, 50% of its gold, 98% of its <a href="/wiki/Chromium" title="Chromium">chromium</a>, 70% of its <a href="/wiki/Tantalite" title="Tantalite">tantalite</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> 64% of its <a href="/wiki/Manganese" title="Manganese">manganese</a> and one-third of its <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo" title="Democratic Republic of the Congo">Democratic Republic of the Congo</a> (DRC) has 70% of the world's <a href="/wiki/Coltan" title="Coltan">coltan</a>, a mineral used in the production of <a href="/wiki/Tantalum_capacitor" title="Tantalum capacitor">tantalum capacitors</a> for electronic devices such as cell phones. The DRC also has more than 30% of the world's diamond reserves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Guinea" title="Guinea">Guinea</a> is the world's largest exporter of <a href="/wiki/Bauxite" title="Bauxite">bauxite</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> As the growth in Africa has been driven mainly by services and not manufacturing or agriculture, it has been growth without jobs and without reduction in <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Africa" title="Poverty in Africa">poverty</a> levels. In fact, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_world_food_price_crisis" title="2007–08 world food price crisis">food security crisis of 2008</a> which took place on the heels of the global financial crisis pushed 100 million people into food insecurity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, the People's Republic of China has built increasingly stronger ties with African nations and is Africa's largest trading partner. In 2007, Chinese companies invested a total of US$1 billion in Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Africa_124-1"><a href="#cite_note-Africa-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>A Harvard University study led by professor <a href="/wiki/Calestous_Juma" title="Calestous Juma">Calestous Juma</a> showed that Africa could feed itself by making the transition from importer to self-sufficiency. "African agriculture is at the crossroads; we have come to the end of a century of policies that favoured Africa's export of raw materials and importation of food. Africa is starting to focus on agricultural innovation as its new engine for regional trade and prosperity."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Africa" title="Demographics of Africa">Demographics of Africa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genetic_history_of_Africa" title="Genetic history of Africa">Genetic history of Africa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage#Africa" title="Child marriage">Child marriage in Africa</a></div>
<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">
