<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#E72"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 522.43475077176px 100px 0; border-right-color:#E33"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:#E33"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 196.87225848326px 100px 0; border-right-color:#928"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:#928"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 106.08774085197px 100px 0; border-right-color:#CC5"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:#CC5"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 42.529898085737px 100px 0; border-right-color:#6A5"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:#6A5"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:0.3082666266872px; border-width:0 0 99.691733373313px 7.8459095727845px; border-bottom-color:#1A9"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:17.718090360442px; border-width:0 0 82.281909639558px 56.830338254032px; border-bottom-color:#36A"></div>
</div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<p><a href="/wiki/List_of_African_countries_by_population" title="List of African countries by population">Proportion of total African population by country</a>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#36A; color:white;"> </span> Nigeria (15.38%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#1A9; color:black;"> </span> Ethiopia (8.37%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#6A5; color:black;"> </span> Egypt (7.65%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#CC5; color:black;"> </span> Democratic Republic of the Congo (6.57%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#928; color:white;"> </span> Tanzania (4.55%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#E33; color:black;"> </span> South Africa (4.47%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#E72; color:black;"> </span> Kenya (3.88%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FE3; color:black;"> </span> Uganda (3.38%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#A45; color:white;"> </span> Algeria (3.36%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white; color:black;"> </span> Other (42.39%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Africa's population has rapidly increased over the last 40 years, and is consequently relatively young. In some African states, more than half the population is under 25 years of age.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> The total number of people in Africa increased from 229 million in 1950 to 630 million in 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> As of 2021, the population of Africa is estimated at 1.4 billion <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_1-2"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2022_2-2"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2022-2">[2]</a></sup>. Africa's total population surpassing other continents is fairly recent; African population surpassed Europe in the 1990s, while the Americas was overtaken sometime around the year 2000; Africa's rapid population growth is expected to overtake the only two nations currently larger than its population, at roughly the same time – India and China's 1.4 billion people each will swap ranking around the year 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> This increase in number of babies born in Africa compared to the rest of the world is expected to reach approximately 37% in the year 2050, an increase of 21% since 1990 alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>Speakers of <a href="/wiki/Bantu_languages" title="Bantu languages">Bantu languages</a> (part of the <a href="/wiki/Niger%E2%80%93Congo_languages" title="Niger–Congo languages">Niger–Congo</a> family) are the majority in southern, central and southeast Africa. The Bantu-speaking peoples from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Sahel" title="The Sahel">the Sahel</a> progressively expanded over most of Sub-Saharan Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> But there are also several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nilotic" title="Nilotic">Nilotic</a> groups in <a href="/wiki/South_Sudan" title="South Sudan">South Sudan</a> and East Africa, the mixed <a href="/wiki/Swahili_people" title="Swahili people">Swahili people</a> on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Swahili_Coast" title="Swahili Coast">Swahili Coast</a>, and a few remaining <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_Africa" title="Indigenous peoples of Africa">indigenous</a> Khoisan ("<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bushmen" title="Bushmen">San"</a> or "Bushmen") and <a href="/wiki/Pygmy_peoples" title="Pygmy peoples">Pygmy peoples</a> in southern and central Africa, respectively. Bantu-speaking Africans also predominate in Gabon and Equatorial Guinea, and are found in parts of southern Cameroon. In the <a href="/wiki/Kalahari_Desert" title="Kalahari Desert">Kalahari Desert</a> of Southern Africa, the distinct people known as the Bushmen (also "San", closely related to, but distinct from "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khoikhoi" title="Khoikhoi">Hottentots</a>") have long been present. The San are physically distinct from other Africans and are the indigenous people of southern Africa. Pygmies are the pre-Bantu indigenous peoples of central Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>The peoples of West Africa primarily speak <a href="/wiki/Niger%E2%80%93Congo_languages" title="Niger–Congo languages">Niger–Congo languages</a>, belonging mostly to its non-Bantu branches, though some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nilo-Saharan" title="Nilo-Saharan">Nilo-Saharan</a> and Afro-Asiatic speaking groups are also found. The Niger–Congo-speaking <a href="/wiki/Yoruba_language" title="Yoruba language">Yoruba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Igbo_language" title="Igbo language">Igbo</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fulani" title="Fulani">Fulani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Akan_language" title="Akan language">Akan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wolof_people" title="Wolof people">Wolof</a> ethnic groups are the largest and most influential. In the central Sahara, <a href="/wiki/Mandinka_people" title="Mandinka people">Mandinka</a> or <a href="/wiki/Mande_languages" title="Mande languages">Mande</a> groups are most significant. Chadic-speaking groups, including the <a href="/wiki/Hausa_language" title="Hausa language">Hausa</a>, are found in more northerly parts of the region nearest to the Sahara, and Nilo-Saharan communities, such as the <a href="/wiki/Songhai_people" title="Songhai people">Songhai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanuri_people" title="Kanuri people">Kanuri</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zarma_people" title="Zarma people">Zarma</a>, are found in the eastern parts of West Africa bordering Central Africa.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:African_countries_by_HDI_(2019).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4670" data-file-width="4665" decoding="async" height="260" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/African_countries_by_HDI_%282019%29.png/260px-African_countries_by_HDI_%282019%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/African_countries_by_HDI_%282019%29.png/390px-African_countries_by_HDI_%282019%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/African_countries_by_HDI_%282019%29.png/520px-African_countries_by_HDI_%282019%29.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:African_countries_by_HDI_(2019).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><table style="background:transparent;" width="100%"> <tbody><tr> <td>Map of Africa indicating <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> (2018). </td></tr> <tr> <td> <div> <table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;"> <tbody><tr> <td style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;"> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00C400; color:black;"> </span> 0.800–0.849</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00F900; color:black;"> </span> 0.750–0.799</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#D3FF00; color:black;"> </span> 0.700–0.749</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFFF00; color:black;"> </span> 0.650–0.699</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFD215; color:black;"> </span> 0.600–0.649</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFA83C; color:black;"> </span> 0.550–0.599</div> </td> <td style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;"> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF852F; color:black;"> </span> 0.500–0.549</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF5B00; color:black;"> </span> 0.450–0.499</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF0000; color:black;"> </span> 0.400–0.449</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#A70000; color:white;"> </span> ≤ 0.399</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#D9D9D9; color:black;"> </span> No data</div> </td></tr></tbody></table></div> </td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>
<p>The peoples of North Africa consist of three main indigenous groups: Berbers in the northwest, Egyptians in the northeast, and Nilo-Saharan-speaking peoples in the east. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab" title="Arab">Arabs</a> who arrived in the 7th century AD introduced the Arabic language and Islam to North Africa. The Semitic <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicians</a> (who founded <a href="/wiki/Carthage" title="Carthage">Carthage</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Hyksos" title="Hyksos">Hyksos</a>, the Indo-Iranian <a href="/wiki/Alans" title="Alans">Alans</a>, the Indo- European <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greeks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Romans</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vandals" title="Vandals">Vandals</a> settled in North Africa as well. Significant Berber communities remain within <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a> in the 21st century, while, to a lesser extent, Berber speakers are also present in some regions of Tunisia and Libya.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> The Berber-speaking <a href="/wiki/Tuareg_people" title="Tuareg people">Tuareg</a> and other often-<a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">nomadic</a> peoples are the principal inhabitants of the Saharan interior of North Africa. In Mauritania, there is a small but near-extinct Berber community in the north and Niger–Congo-speaking peoples in the south, though in both regions Arabic and Arab culture predominates. In Sudan, although Arabic and Arab culture predominate, it is mostly inhabited by groups that originally spoke Nilo-Saharan, such as the Nubians, Fur, Masalit and Zaghawa, who, over the centuries, have variously intermixed with migrants from the Arabian peninsula. Small communities of Afro-Asiatic-speaking Beja nomads can also be found in Egypt and Sudan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a>, some Ethiopian and Eritrean groups (like the <a href="/wiki/Amhara_people" title="Amhara people">Amhara</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tigrayans" title="Tigrayans">Tigrayans</a>, collectively known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habesha_people" title="Habesha people">Habesha</a>) speak languages from the <a href="/wiki/Semitic_languages" title="Semitic languages">Semitic</a> branch of the <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages">Afro-Asiatic</a> language family, while the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Somalis" title="Somalis">Somali</a> speak languages from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cushitic" title="Cushitic">Cushitic</a> branch of Afro-Asiatic.
</p><p>Prior to the <a href="/wiki/Decolonization" title="Decolonization">decolonization</a> movements of the post-<a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> era, <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Europe" title="Ethnic groups in Europe">Europeans</a> were represented in every part of Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> Decolonization during the 1960s and 1970s often resulted in the mass emigration of white settlers – especially from Algeria and Morocco (1.6 million <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pieds-noir" title="Pieds-noir">pieds-noirs</a></i> in North Africa),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> Kenya, Congo,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> Rhodesia, Mozambique and Angola.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> Between 1975 and 1977, over a million colonials returned to Portugal alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> Nevertheless, <a href="/wiki/White_Africans_of_European_ancestry" title="White Africans of European ancestry">white Africans</a> remain an important minority in many African states, particularly <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Namibia" title="Namibia">Namibia</a>, <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9union" title="Réunion">Réunion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> The country with the largest white African population is South Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dutch_people" title="Dutch people">Dutch</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_diaspora_in_Africa" title="British diaspora in Africa">British</a> <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diasporas</a> represent the largest communities of European ancestry on the continent today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-World-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>European colonization also brought sizable groups of <a href="/wiki/Asian_people" title="Asian people">Asians</a>, particularly from the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>, to British colonies. Large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-resident_Indian_and_person_of_Indian_origin" title="Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin">Indian communities</a> are found in South Africa, and smaller ones are present in Kenya, Tanzania, and some other southern and southeast African countries. The large <a href="/wiki/Indians_in_Uganda" title="Indians in Uganda">Indian community in Uganda</a> was <a href="/wiki/Expulsion_of_Asians_from_Uganda" title="Expulsion of Asians from Uganda">expelled</a> by the dictator <a href="/wiki/Idi_Amin" title="Idi Amin">Idi Amin</a> in 1972, though many have since returned. The islands in the Indian Ocean are also populated primarily by people of Asian origin, often mixed with Africans and Europeans. The <a href="/wiki/Malagasy_people" title="Malagasy people">Malagasy people</a> of <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">Madagascar</a> are an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austronesian_people" title="Austronesian people">Austronesian people</a>, but those along the coast are generally mixed with Bantu, Arab, Indian and European origins. Malay and Indian ancestries are also important components in the group of people known in South Africa as <a href="/wiki/Cape_Coloureds" title="Cape Coloureds">Cape Coloureds</a> (people with origins in two or more races and continents). During the 20th century, small but economically important communities of <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Lebanon#The_Lebanese_Diaspora" title="Demographics of Lebanon">Lebanese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese" title="Overseas Chinese">Chinese</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Africa_124-2"><a href="#cite_note-Africa-124">[124]</a></sup> have also developed in the larger coastal cities of <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West</a> and East Africa, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Religion_distribution_Africa_crop.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="353" data-file-width="367" decoding="async" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Religion_distribution_Africa_crop.png/240px-Religion_distribution_Africa_crop.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Religion_distribution_Africa_crop.png/360px-Religion_distribution_Africa_crop.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7f/Religion_distribution_Africa_crop.png 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Religion_distribution_Africa_crop.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map showing religious distribution in Africa</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Africa" title="Religion in Africa">Religion in Africa</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/African_divination" title="African divination">African divination</a></div>
<p>While Africans profess a wide variety of religious beliefs, the majority of the people respect African religions or parts of them. However, in formal surveys or census, most people will identify with major religions that came from outside the continent, mainly through colonisation. There are several reasons for this, the main one being the colonial idea that African religious beliefs and practices are not good enough. Religious beliefs and statistics on religious affiliation are difficult to come by since they are often a sensitive topic for governments with mixed religious populations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stanford_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-stanford-204">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-205">[205]</a></sup> According to the <i><a href="/wiki/World_Book_Encyclopedia" title="World Book Encyclopedia">World Book Encyclopedia</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Africa" title="Islam in Africa">Islam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Africa" title="Christianity in Africa">Christianity</a> are the two largest religions in Africa. According to <a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a>, 45% of the population are Christians, 40% are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslims</a>, and 10% follow <a href="/wiki/Traditional_African_religions" title="Traditional African religions">traditional religions</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> A small number of Africans are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confucianist" title="Confucianist">Confucianist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Baháʼí</a>, or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judaism_in_Africa" title="Judaism in Africa">Jewish</a>. There is also a minority of people in Africa who are <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Africa" title="Irreligion in Africa">irreligious</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Africa" title="Languages of Africa">Languages of Africa</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Writing_systems_of_Africa#Indigenous_writing_systems" title="Writing systems of Africa">Writing systems of Africa § Indigenous writing systems</a></div>
<p>By most estimates, well over a thousand <a href="/wiki/Language" title="Language">languages</a> (<a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> has estimated around two thousand) are spoken in Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> Most are of African origin, though some are of European or Asian origin. Africa is the most <a href="/wiki/Multilingualism" title="Multilingualism">multilingual</a> continent in the world, and it is not rare for individuals to fluently speak not only multiple African languages, but one or more European ones as well. There are four major <a href="/wiki/Language_family" title="Language family">language families</a> indigenous to Africa:
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_African_language_families.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1440" data-file-width="1525" decoding="async" height="246" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Map_of_African_language_families.svg/260px-Map_of_African_language_families.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Map_of_African_language_families.svg/390px-Map_of_African_language_families.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Map_of_African_language_families.svg/520px-Map_of_African_language_families.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_African_language_families.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A simplistic view of language families spoken in Africa</div></div></div>
<ul><li>The <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages"><i>Afroasiatic</i></a> languages are a language family of about 240 languages and 285 million people widespread throughout the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a>, North Africa, the <a href="/wiki/Sahel" title="Sahel">Sahel</a>, and Southwest Asia.</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Nilo-Saharan_languages" title="Nilo-Saharan languages"><i>Nilo-Saharan</i></a> language family consists of more than a hundred languages spoken by 30 million people. Nilo-Saharan languages are spoken by ethnic groups in <a href="/wiki/Chad" title="Chad">Chad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">Kenya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Sudan" title="South Sudan">South Sudan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uganda" title="Uganda">Uganda</a>, and northern <a href="/wiki/Tanzania" title="Tanzania">Tanzania</a>.</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Niger%E2%80%93Congo_languages" title="Niger–Congo languages"><i>Niger-Congo</i></a> language family covers much of Sub-Saharan Africa. In terms of number of languages, it is the largest language family in Africa and perhaps one of the largest in the world.</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Khoisan_languages" title="Khoisan languages"><i>Khoisan</i></a> languages number about fifty and are spoken in Southern Africa by approximately 400,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> Many of the Khoisan languages are <a href="/wiki/Endangered_language" title="Endangered language">endangered</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khoikhoi" title="Khoikhoi">Khoi</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bushmen" title="Bushmen">San</a> peoples are considered the original inhabitants of this part of Africa.</li></ul>
<p>Following the end of <a href="/wiki/Colonialism" title="Colonialism">colonialism</a>, nearly all African countries adopted <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official languages</a> that originated outside the continent, although several countries also granted legal recognition to indigenous languages (such as <a href="/wiki/Swahili_language" title="Swahili language">Swahili</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yoruba_language" title="Yoruba language">Yoruba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Igbo_language" title="Igbo language">Igbo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hausa_language" title="Hausa language">Hausa</a>). In numerous countries, English and French (<i>see <a href="/wiki/African_French" title="African French">African French</a></i>) are used for communication in the public sphere such as government, commerce, education and the media. Arabic, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afrikaans" title="Afrikaans">Afrikaans</a> and Spanish are examples of languages that trace their origin to outside of Africa, and that are used by millions of Africans today, both in the public and private spheres. Italian is spoken by some in former <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_Colonial_Empire" title="Italian Colonial Empire">Italian colonies</a> in Africa. German is spoken in <a href="/wiki/Namibia" title="Namibia">Namibia</a>, as it was a former German protectorate.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HIV_in_Africa_2011.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/HIV_in_Africa_2011.svg/240px-HIV_in_Africa_2011.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/HIV_in_Africa_2011.svg/360px-HIV_in_Africa_2011.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/HIV_in_Africa_2011.svg/480px-HIV_in_Africa_2011.svg.png 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HIV_in_Africa_2011.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Prevalence of HIV/AIDS in Africa, total (% of population ages 15–49), in 2011 (<a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>) <table style="width:100%;"> <tbody><tr> <td valign="top"> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#2b0000; color:white;"> </span> over 15%</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#800000; color:white;"> </span> 5–15%</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#d40000; color:white;"> </span> 2–5%</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff2a2a; color:black;"> </span> 1–2%</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff9955; color:black;"> </span> 0.5-1%</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffb380; color:black;"> </span> 0.1–0.5%</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#b9b9b9; color:black;"> </span> not available</div> </td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>
<p>More than 85% of individuals in Africa use traditional medicine as an alternative to often expensive allopathic medical health care and costly pharmaceutical products. The <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_African_Unity" title="Organisation of African Unity">Organization of African Unity</a> (OAU) Heads of State and Government declared the 2000s decade as the African Decade on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_traditional_medicine" title="African traditional medicine">African traditional medicine</a> in an effort to promote The WHO African Region's adopted resolution for institutionalizing traditional medicine in health care systems across the continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> Public policy makers in the region are challenged with consideration of the importance of traditional/indigenous health systems and whether their coexistence with the modern medical and health sub-sector would improve the equitability and accessibility of health care distribution, the health status of populations, and the social-economic development of nations within sub-Saharan Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS_in_Africa" title="HIV/AIDS in Africa">AIDS in post-colonial Africa</a> is a prevalent issue. Although the continent is home to about 15.2 percent of the world's population,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> more than two-thirds of the total infected worldwide – some 35 million people – were Africans, of whom 15 million have already died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-211">[211]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a> alone accounted for an estimated 69 percent of all people living with HIV<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2012_Facts_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-2012_Facts-212">[212]</a></sup> and 70 percent of all AIDS deaths in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dUNAIDSi_ck_2012_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-dUNAIDSi_ck_2012-213">[213]</a></sup> In the countries of sub-Saharan Africa most affected, AIDS has raised death rates and lowered life expectancy among adults between the ages of 20 and 49 by about twenty years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_211-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-211">[211]</a></sup> Furthermore, the life expectancy in many parts of Africa is declining, largely as a result of the HIV/AIDS epidemic with life-expectancy in some countries reaching as low as thirty-four years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Africa" title="Culture of Africa">Culture of Africa</a></div>
<p>Some aspects of traditional African cultures have become less practised in recent years as a result of neglect and suppression by colonial and post-colonial regimes. For example, African customs were discouraged, and African languages were prohibited in mission schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearsonhighered.com_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-pearsonhighered.com-215">[215]</a></sup> Leopold II of Belgium attempted to "civilize" Africans by discouraging polygamy and witchcraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearsonhighered.com_215-1"><a href="#cite_note-pearsonhighered.com-215">[215]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bet_Giyorgis_church_Lalibela_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2136" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Bet_Giyorgis_church_Lalibela_01.jpg/220px-Bet_Giyorgis_church_Lalibela_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Bet_Giyorgis_church_Lalibela_01.jpg/330px-Bet_Giyorgis_church_Lalibela_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Bet_Giyorgis_church_Lalibela_01.jpg/440px-Bet_Giyorgis_church_Lalibela_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bet_Giyorgis_church_Lalibela_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The rock-hewn <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Saint_George,_Lalibela" title="Church of Saint George, Lalibela">Church of Saint George</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lalibela" title="Lalibela">Lalibela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a> is a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Obidoh Freeborn posits that colonialism is one element that has created the character of modern African art.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> According to authors Douglas Fraser and Herbert M. Cole, "The precipitous alterations in the power structure wrought by colonialism were quickly followed by drastic iconographic changes in the art."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.com_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-217">[217]</a></sup> Fraser and Cole assert that, in Igboland, some art objects "lack the vigor and careful craftsmanship of the earlier art objects that served traditional functions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.com_217-1"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-217">[217]</a></sup> Author Chika Okeke-Agulu states that "the racist infrastructure of British imperial enterprise forced upon the political and cultural guardians of empire a denial and suppression of an emergent sovereign Africa and modernist art."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> Editors F. Abiola Irele and Simon Gikandi comment that the current identity of African literature had its genesis in the "traumatic encounter between Africa and Europe."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> On the other hand, Mhoze Chikowero believes that Africans deployed music, dance, spirituality, and other performative cultures to (re)asset themselves as active agents and indigenous intellectuals, to unmake their colonial marginalization and reshape their own destinies."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is now a resurgence in the attempts to rediscover and revalue African traditional cultures, under such movements as the <a href="/wiki/African_Renaissance" title="African Renaissance">African Renaissance</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/Thabo_Mbeki" title="Thabo Mbeki">Thabo Mbeki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afrocentrism" title="Afrocentrism">Afrocentrism</a>, led by a group of scholars, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Molefi_Asante" title="Molefi Asante">Molefi Asante</a>, as well as the increasing recognition of traditional spiritualism through decriminalization of <a href="/wiki/West_African_Vodun" title="West African Vodun">Vodou</a> and other forms of spirituality.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_art">Visual art</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nok_sculpture_Louvre_70-1998-11-1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2500" data-file-width="1660" decoding="async" height="361" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Nok_sculpture_Louvre_70-1998-11-1.jpg/240px-Nok_sculpture_Louvre_70-1998-11-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Nok_sculpture_Louvre_70-1998-11-1.jpg/360px-Nok_sculpture_Louvre_70-1998-11-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Nok_sculpture_Louvre_70-1998-11-1.jpg/480px-Nok_sculpture_Louvre_70-1998-11-1.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nok_sculpture_Louvre_70-1998-11-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Nok_culture" title="Nok culture">Nok</a> figure (5th century BC-5th century AD)</div></div></div>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">These paragraphs are an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/African_art" title="African art">African art</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=African_art&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<p><a href="/wiki/African_art" title="African art">African art</a> describes the modern and historical paintings, sculptures, installations, and other <a href="/wiki/Visual_culture" title="Visual culture">visual culture</a> from native or indigenous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa" title="Ethnic groups of Africa">Africans</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_continent" title="African continent">African continent</a>. The definition may also include the art of the <a href="/wiki/African_diaspora" title="African diaspora">African diasporas</a>, such as: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">African American</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> or art in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South American</a> societies inspired by African traditions. Despite this diversity, there are unifying artistic themes present when considering the totality of the visual culture from the continent of Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pottery, <a href="/wiki/Metalworking" title="Metalworking">metalwork</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sculpture" title="Sculpture">sculpture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Africa" title="Architecture of Africa">architecture</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Textile_art" title="Textile art">textile art</a> and fibre art are important visual art forms across Africa and may be included in the study of African art. The term "African art" does not usually include the art of the <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North African</a> areas along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> coast, as such areas had long been part of different traditions. For more than a millennium, the art of such areas had formed part of <a href="/wiki/Berbers" title="Berbers">Berber</a> or <a href="/wiki/Islamic_art" title="Islamic art">Islamic art</a>, although with many particular local characteristics.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art_of_Ethiopia" title="Art of Ethiopia">Art of Ethiopia</a>, with a long <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Christian tradition</a>, is also different from that of most of Africa, where <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_African_religion" title="Traditional African religion">Traditional African religion</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> in the north) was dominant until the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-African_art_nytimes_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-African_art_nytimes-222">[222]</a></sup> African art includes <a href="/wiki/Prehistory" title="Prehistory">prehistoric</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_history" title="Ancient history">ancient</a> art, Islamic art of <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West Africa</a>, the Christian art of <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">East Africa</a>, and the traditional <a href="/wiki/Artifact_(archaeology)" title="Artifact (archaeology)">artifacts</a> of these and other regions. Much <a href="/wiki/African_sculpture" title="African sculpture">African sculpture</a> was historically in wood and other natural materials that have not survived from earlier than a few centuries ago, although rare older <a href="/wiki/Pottery#Africa" title="Pottery">Pottery</a> and metal figures can be found from a number of areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> Some of the earliest decorative objects, such as shell beads and evidence of paint, have been discovered in Africa, dating to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Stone_Age" title="Middle Stone Age">Middle Stone Age</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-African_art_Mitchell_2013_p._375_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-African_art_Mitchell_2013_p._375-224">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-African_art_Henshilwood_et_al._2011_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-African_art_Henshilwood_et_al._2011-225">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-African_art_McBrearty_Brooks_2000_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-African_art_McBrearty_Brooks_2000-226">[226]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Traditional_African_masks" title="Traditional African masks">Masks</a> are important elements in the art of many peoples, along with human figures, and are often highly Stylized. There is a vast variety of styles, often varying within the same context of origin and depending on the use of the object, but wide regional trends are apparent; sculpture is most common among "groups of settled cultivators in the areas drained by the <a href="/wiki/Niger" title="Niger">Niger</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congo_river" title="Congo river">Congo rivers</a>" in West Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-African_art_Honour_&amp;_Fleming,_557_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-African_art_Honour_&amp;_Fleming,_557-227">[227]</a></sup> Direct images of deities are relatively infrequent, but masks in particular are or were often made for ritual ceremonies. Since the late 19th century there has been an increasing amount of <a href="/wiki/African_art_in_Western_collections" title="African art in Western collections">African art in Western collections</a>, the finest pieces of which are displayed as part of the history of colonization.
</p><p>African art has had an important influence on European <a href="/wiki/Modernism" title="Modernism">Modernist</a> art,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-African_art_African_Influences_in_Modern_Art_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-African_art_African_Influences_in_Modern_Art-228">[228]</a></sup> which was inspired by their interest in abstract depiction. It was this appreciation of African sculpture that has been attributed to the very concept of "African art", as seen by European and American artists and art historians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup>
</p>
West African cultures developed bronze casting for reliefs, like the famous <a href="/wiki/Benin_Bronzes" title="Benin Bronzes">Benin Bronzes</a>, to decorate palaces and for highly <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">naturalistic</a> royal heads from around the <a href="/wiki/Edo_people" title="Edo people">Bini</a> town of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benin_Empire" title="Benin Empire">Benin City, Edo State</a>, as well as in terracotta or metal, from the 12th–14th centuries. <a href="/wiki/Akan_goldweights" title="Akan goldweights">Akan gold weights</a> are a form of small metal sculptures produced over the period 1400–1900; some apparently represent <a href="/wiki/Proverb" title="Proverb">proverbs</a>, contributing a narrative element rare in African sculpture; and royal regalia included impressive gold sculptured elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup>  Many West African figures are used in religious rituals and are often coated with materials placed on them for ceremonial offerings. The <a href="/wiki/Mand%C3%A9_peoples" title="Mandé peoples">Mande</a>-speaking peoples of the same region make pieces from wood with broad, flat surfaces and arms and legs shaped like cylinders. In <a href="/wiki/Central_Africa" title="Central Africa">Central Africa</a>, however, the main distinguishing characteristics include heart-shaped faces that are curved inward and display patterns of circles and dots.</div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Africa" title="Architecture of Africa">Architecture of Africa</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Architecture_of_Africa&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2906" data-file-width="4372" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg/250px-All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg/375px-All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg/500px-All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Giza_pyramid_complex" title="Giza pyramid complex">Great Pyramids of Giza</a> are regarded as one of the greatest architectural feats of all time and are one of <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">Seven Wonders of the Ancient World</a></div></div></div>
<p>Like other aspects of the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Africa" title="Culture of Africa">culture of Africa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Africa" title="Architecture of Africa">architecture of Africa</a> is exceptionally diverse. Throughout the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Africa" title="History of Africa">history of Africa</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_people" title="African people">Africans</a> have developed their own local <a href="/wiki/Architecture" title="Architecture">architectural</a> traditions. In some cases, broader regional styles can be identified, such as the <a href="/wiki/Sudano-Sahelian_architecture" title="Sudano-Sahelian architecture">Sudano-Sahelian architecture</a> of <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West Africa</a>. A common theme in traditional African architecture is the use of <a href="/wiki/Fractal" title="Fractal">fractal</a> scaling: small parts of the structure tend to look similar to larger parts, such as a circular village made of circular houses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup>
</p><p>African architecture in some areas has been influenced by external cultures for centuries, according to available evidence. Western architecture has influenced coastal areas since the late 15th century and is now an important source of inspiration for many larger buildings, particularly in major cities.
</p>
African architecture uses a wide range of materials, including thatch, stick/wood, mud, <a href="/wiki/Mudbrick" title="Mudbrick">mudbrick</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rammed_earth" title="Rammed earth">rammed earth</a>, and stone. These material preferences vary by region: North Africa for stone and rammed earth, the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a> for stone and mortar, West Africa for mud/adobe, Central Africa for thatch/wood and more perishable materials, Southeast and Southern Africa for stone and thatch/wood.</div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Africa" title="Cinema of Africa">Cinema of Africa</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cinema_of_Africa&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Straatgezicht_met_filmposter_Tunis_TMnr_20013070.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="684" data-file-width="700" decoding="async" height="283" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Straatgezicht_met_filmposter_Tunis_TMnr_20013070.jpg/290px-COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Straatgezicht_met_filmposter_Tunis_TMnr_20013070.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Straatgezicht_met_filmposter_Tunis_TMnr_20013070.jpg/435px-COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Straatgezicht_met_filmposter_Tunis_TMnr_20013070.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Straatgezicht_met_filmposter_Tunis_TMnr_20013070.jpg/580px-COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Straatgezicht_met_filmposter_Tunis_TMnr_20013070.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Straatgezicht_met_filmposter_Tunis_TMnr_20013070.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Cinematic poster in <a href="/wiki/Tunis" title="Tunis">Tunis</a> for the Egyptian film <i><a href="/wiki/Saladin_the_Victorious" title="Saladin the Victorious">Saladin the Victorious</a></i> (1963)</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Africa" title="Cinema of Africa">Cinema of Africa</a> is both the <a href="/wiki/History_of_film" title="History of film">history</a> and present of the <a href="/wiki/Filmmaking" title="Filmmaking">making</a> or screening of films on the African continent, and also refers to the persons involved in this form of <a href="/wiki/Audiovisual" title="Audiovisual">audiovisual</a> culture. It dates back to the early 20th century, when film reels were the primary cinematic technology in use. During the <a href="/wiki/Colonialism" title="Colonialism">colonial era</a>, African life was shown only by the work of white, colonial, Western filmmakers, who depicted Africans in a negative fashion, as exotic "others".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cinema_of_Africa_Hayward,_Susan_2006._p._426-442_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cinema_of_Africa_Hayward,_Susan_2006._p._426-442-232">[232]</a></sup> As there are more than 50 countries with audiovisual traditions, there is no one single 'African cinema'. Both historically and culturally, there are major regional differences between <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North African</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">sub-Saharan</a> cinemas, and between the cinemas of different countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cinema_of_Africa_Hayward,_Susan_2006._p._426-442_232-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cinema_of_Africa_Hayward,_Susan_2006._p._426-442-232">[232]</a></sup>
</p>
The <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Tunisia" title="Cinema of Tunisia">cinema of Tunisia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Egypt" title="Cinema of Egypt">cinema of Egypt</a> are among the oldest in the world. Pioneers <a href="/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re" title="Auguste and Louis Lumière">Auguste and Louis Lumière</a> screened their films in Alexandria, Cairo, Tunis, Soussa and Hammam-Lif in 1896.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Albert_Samama_Chikly" title="Albert Samama Chikly">Albert Samama Chikly</a> is often cited as the first producer of indigenous African cinema, screening his own short documentaries in the casino of Tunis as early as December 1905.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cinema_of_Africa_Ritrovato_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cinema_of_Africa_Ritrovato-235">[235]</a></sup> Alongside his daughter <a href="/wiki/Hayd%C3%A9e_Tamzali" title="Haydée Tamzali">Haydée Tamzali</a>, Chikly would go on to produce important early milestones such as 1924's <i><a href="/wiki/The_Girl_from_Carthage" title="The Girl from Carthage">The Girl from Carthage</a></i>. In 1935 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MISR_film" title="MISR film">MISR film</a> studio in Cairo began producing mostly formulaic comedies and musicals, but also films like Kamal Selim's <i><a href="/wiki/The_Will_(1939_film)" title="The Will (1939 film)">The Will</a></i> (1939). Egyptian cinema flourished in the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s, considered its Golden Age.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Youssef_Chahine" title="Youssef Chahine">Youssef Chahine</a>'s seminal <i><a href="/wiki/Cairo_Station" title="Cairo Station">Cairo Station</a></i> (1958) foreshadowed Hitchcock's <i><a href="/wiki/Psycho_(1960_film)" title="Psycho (1960 film)">Psycho</a></i> and laid a foundation for Arab film.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ke-Nako_Music-Performance_Vienna2008c.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1558" data-file-width="780" decoding="async" height="300" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ke-Nako_Music-Performance_Vienna2008c.jpg/150px-Ke-Nako_Music-Performance_Vienna2008c.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ke-Nako_Music-Performance_Vienna2008c.jpg/225px-Ke-Nako_Music-Performance_Vienna2008c.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ke-Nako_Music-Performance_Vienna2008c.jpg/300px-Ke-Nako_Music-Performance_Vienna2008c.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ke-Nako_Music-Performance_Vienna2008c.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A musician from South Africa</div></div></div>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Africa" title="Music of Africa">Music of Africa</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Music_of_Africa&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<p>Given the vastness of the African continent, its music is diverse, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regions_of_Africa" title="Regions of Africa">regions</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_African_countries" title="List of African countries">nations</a> having many distinct <a href="/wiki/Music" title="Music">musical</a> traditions. African music includes the genres <a href="/wiki/Amapiano" title="Amapiano">amapiano</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B9j%C3%BA_music" title="Jùjú music">Jùjú</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fuji_music" title="Fuji music">Fuji</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afrobeat" title="Afrobeat">Afrobeat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Highlife" title="Highlife">Highlife</a>, <a href="/wiki/Makossa" title="Makossa">Makossa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kizomba" title="Kizomba">Kizomba</a>, and others. The music and dance of the <a href="/wiki/African_diaspora" title="African diaspora">African diaspora</a>, formed to varying degrees on African musical traditions, include <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States" title="Music of the United States">American music</a> like <a href="/wiki/Dixieland_jazz" title="Dixieland jazz">Dixieland jazz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blues" title="Blues">blues</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>, and many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caribbean_music" title="Caribbean music">Caribbean</a> genres, such as <a href="/wiki/Calypso_music" title="Calypso music">calypso</a> (see <a href="/wiki/Kaiso" title="Kaiso">kaiso</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Soca_music" title="Soca music">soca</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_American_music" title="Latin American music">Latin American music</a> genres such as <a href="/wiki/Cumbia" title="Cumbia">cumbia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Conga_(music)" title="Conga (music)">conga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuban_rumba" title="Cuban rumba">rumba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Son_cubano" title="Son cubano">son cubano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salsa_music" title="Salsa music">salsa music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bomba_(Puerto_Rico)" title="Bomba (Puerto Rico)">bomba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samba" title="Samba">samba</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zouk_(musical_movement)" title="Zouk (musical movement)">zouk</a> were founded on the music of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trans-Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Trans-Atlantic slave trade">enslaved Africans</a>, and have in turn influenced <a href="/wiki/African_popular_music" title="African popular music">African popular music</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Music_of_Africa_Columbia_University_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Music_of_Africa_Columbia_University-238">[238]</a></sup>
</p>
Like the music of Asia, India and the Middle East, it is a highly rhythmic music. The complex rhythmic patterns often involving one rhythm played against another to create a <a href="/wiki/Polyrhythm" title="Polyrhythm">polyrhythm</a>. The most common polyrhythm plays three beats on top of two, like a triplet played against straight notes. <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_African_music_traditions" title="Sub-Saharan African music traditions">Sub-Saharan African music traditions</a> frequently rely on percussion instruments of many varieties, including <a href="/wiki/Xylophone" title="Xylophone">xylophones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Djembe" title="Djembe">djembes</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Drums" title="Drums">drums</a>, and tone-producing instruments such as the <a href="/wiki/Mbira" title="Mbira">mbira</a> or "thumb piano."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Music_of_Africa_Columbia_University_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-Music_of_Africa_Columbia_University-238">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dance">Dance</span></h3>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/African_dance" title="African dance">African dance</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=African_dance&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<a href="/wiki/African_dance" title="African dance">African dance</a> refers to the various dance styles of <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a>. These dances are closely connected with the traditional <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Rhythm in Sub-Saharan Africa">rhythms</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_African_music_traditions" title="Sub-Saharan African music traditions">music traditions</a> of the region. Music and dancing is an integral part of many traditional African societies. Songs and dances facilitate teaching and promoting social values, celebrating special events and major life milestones, performing <a href="/wiki/Oral_history" title="Oral history">oral history</a> and other recitations, and spiritual experiences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMalone19969_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMalone19969-240">[240]</a></sup> African dance utilizes the concepts of <a href="/wiki/Polyrhythm" title="Polyrhythm">polyrhythm</a> and total body articulation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWelsh-Asante200928_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWelsh-Asante200928-241">[241]</a></sup>  African dances are a collective activity performed in large groups, with significant interaction between dancers and onlookers in the majority of styles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWelsh-Asante200935_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWelsh-Asante200935-242">[242]</a></sup></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:World_cup_african_countries_best_results_and_hosts.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="392" data-file-width="360" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/World_cup_african_countries_best_results_and_hosts.png/220px-World_cup_african_countries_best_results_and_hosts.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/World_cup_african_countries_best_results_and_hosts.png/330px-World_cup_african_countries_best_results_and_hosts.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/af/World_cup_african_countries_best_results_and_hosts.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:World_cup_african_countries_best_results_and_hosts.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Best results of African men's national football teams at the FIFA World Cup</div></div></div>
<p>Fifty-four African countries have <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> teams in the <a href="/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football" title="Confederation of African Football">Confederation of African Football</a>. Egypt has won the African Cup seven times, and a record-making three times in a row. Cameroon, Nigeria, Senegal, Ghana, and Algeria have advanced to the knockout stage of recent <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cups</a>. South Africa hosted the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010 World Cup tournament</a>, becoming the first African country to do so. 
The top clubs in each African football league play the <a href="/wiki/CAF_Champions_League" title="CAF Champions League">CAF Champions League</a>, while lower-ranked clubs compete in <a href="/wiki/CAF_Confederation_Cup" title="CAF Confederation Cup">CAF Confederation Cup</a>.
</p><p>In recent years, the continent has made major progress in terms of state-of-the-art <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a> facilities which have been built in cites as diverse as <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dakar" title="Dakar">Dakar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kigali" title="Kigali">Kigali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luanda" title="Luanda">Luanda</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rades" title="Rades">Rades</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup> The number of African basketball players who drafted into the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">NBA</a> has experienced major growth in the 2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">Cricket</a> is popular in some African nations. <a href="/wiki/South_Africa_national_cricket_team" title="South Africa national cricket team">South Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe_national_cricket_team" title="Zimbabwe national cricket team">Zimbabwe</a> have <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test</a> status, while <a href="/wiki/Kenya_national_cricket_team" title="Kenya national cricket team">Kenya</a> is the leading non-test team and previously had <a href="/wiki/One_Day_International" title="One Day International">One-Day International cricket</a> (ODI) status (from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President%27s_Cup_1997-98" title="President's Cup 1997-98">10 October 1997</a>, until <a href="/wiki/2014_Cricket_World_Cup_Qualifier#Super_Six" title="2014 Cricket World Cup Qualifier">30 January 2014</a>). The three countries jointly hosted the <a href="/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2003 Cricket World Cup">2003 Cricket World Cup</a>. <a href="/wiki/Namibia_national_cricket_team" title="Namibia national cricket team">Namibia</a> is the other African country to have played in a World Cup. <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a> in northern Africa has also hosted the <a href="/wiki/2002_Morocco_Cup" title="2002 Morocco Cup">2002 Morocco Cup</a>, but the national team has never qualified for a major tournament.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">Rugby</a> is popular in several southern African nations. <a href="/wiki/Namibia" title="Namibia">Namibia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a> both have appeared on multiple occasions at the <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">Rugby World Cup</a>, while South Africa is the joint-most successful national team (alongside New Zealand) at the Rugby World Cup, having won the tournament on 3 occasions, in 1995, 2007, and 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Territories_and_regions">Territories and regions</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_regions_of_Africa" title="List of regions of Africa">List of regions of Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_in_Africa" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Africa">List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Africa</a></div><div style="clear:both;"></div>
<div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><div class="noresize" role="img" style="width: 400px; padding: 11px; font-size: 85%; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Blank_Map-Africa.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1230" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="410" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Blank_Map-Africa.svg/400px-Blank_Map-Africa.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Blank_Map-Africa.svg/600px-Blank_Map-Africa.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Blank_Map-Africa.svg/800px-Blank_Map-Africa.svg.png 2x" width="400"/></a>

<div style="position:absolute; left:98px; top:230px"><a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Tom%C3%A9_and_Pr%C3%ADncipe" title="São Tomé and Príncipe">São Tomé<br/>and Príncipe*</a></div>

<div style="position:absolute; left:164px; top:124px"><a href="/wiki/Niger" title="Niger">Niger</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:152px; top:172.4px"><a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a></div><div style="position:absolute; left:202px; top:218px"><a href="/wiki/Republic_of_the_Congo" title="Republic of the Congo">Congo</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:368px; top:201.2px"><a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:346px; top:162.4px"><small><a href="/wiki/Somaliland" title="Somaliland">Somaliland</a></small></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:211px; top:391.6px"><a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:265px; top:141px"><a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a></div>

<div style="position:absolute; left:170px; top:28px"><a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:26px; top:68px"><a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">Western<br/>Sahara</a></div>

</div></div>
<p>The countries in this table are categorized according to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_geoscheme_for_Africa" title="United Nations geoscheme for Africa">scheme for geographic subregions</a> used by the United Nations, and data included are per sources in cross-referenced articles. Where they differ, provisos are clearly indicated.
</p>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBayeh2015">Bayeh, Endalcachew (February 2015). <a class="external text" href="https://endbayeh.files.wordpress.com/2015/04/ijciss2513feb7.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The political and economic legacy of colonialism in the post-independence African states"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>International Journal in Commerce, IT &amp; Social Sciences</i>. <b>2</b> (2): 89–93. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:198939744" rel="nofollow">198939744</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20211024172646/https://endbayeh.files.wordpress.com/2015/04/ijciss2513feb7.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 24 October 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-NYT-20190910-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-NYT-20190910_25-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NYT-20190910_25-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFZimmer2019"><a href="/wiki/Carl_Zimmer" title="Carl Zimmer">Zimmer, Carl</a> (10 September 2019). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/10/science/human-ancestor-skull-computer.html" rel="nofollow">"Scientists Find the Skull of Humanity's Ancestor — on a Computer – By comparing fossils and CT scans, researchers say they have reconstructed the skull of the last common forebear of modern humans"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20191231125331/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/10/science/human-ancestor-skull-computer.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 31 December 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">.
